=== FILE: Can You Make the Same GainzZz Lifting Lighter Weights When Fatigued？ [mdfl8aUD844].txt ===

Music Welcome back to the Barbell Medicine YouTube channel. I'm Dr. Jordan Fagginbaum. We have Dr. Awesome Rocky in the studio live in the flesh. That's real. He's in town this week and we decided to answer some questions from the internet. Can lower weights produce similar adaptations if pre-feteed when the RPE is the same? I think this question is like if you're fatigued, right, or otherwise your performance potential is lower on a given day, can reduce the reduced load that you're necessarily having to use to maintain RPE drive similar adaptations than if you had a high performance day, but RPE is still the same. My answer to that is yeah, I mean that's the whole point of using RPE is that you get the correct dose of training stress to drive the fitness adaptations that you want. And so you want something that's the same level of exertion at the same rep scheme, you know, same rest intervals because that's going to produce the same or similar adaptations. And when you go look in the literature there's a much wider range of acceptable training intensities that drive in this case strength adaptations. And when you talk about high-purchary adaptations, that gets even wider which is why you can have very rep schemes that will produce high-purchary fees. So I think the easiest way to think about this is to consider the converse scenario where you don't lower the weight when you're extremely fatigued, right? It stays real heavy and then it's just a lot harder. You're probably not able to do the same number of reps or if you are again the RPE maybe instead of being seven it's 11. That is very obviously going to generate different adaptations as well as generating way more of what we called previously the negative kind of consequences the fatigue cost and things like that. So if you just imagine the other scenario where you just ignore the effects of fatigue and you just throw the weight on the bar anyway that's obviously going to generate different adaptations and different costs compared to adjusting the weight based on where your performance is at that time. Yeah it's just putting too much of an emphasis on the absolute load because it's like the whole reason for using RPE is to effectively arrive at a similar intensity like relative intensity on a given day with changing performance. So it's like let's say that the RPE that you're using for the reps scheme is you know once you do use somewhere between 70 to 75% of your one-rette and on a day when you have high level of performance that happens to be heavier. Yeah but on a day when you have reduced level of performance it's lower. It's like okay it was still 70 to 75% just your one-art M change for the day.

=== FILE: Does Exercise Work For Everyone？ [2fIsCmTZtvU].txt ===

Alright, when discussing the Ateon in 2006 study, we saw people who did not respond to the training program, are there any follow-up studies that show that initial non-responders do in fact respond when presented with the appropriate stimulus? Yes, there are. There are a number of studies and this idea of non-response to exercise is pretty interesting. It's been discussed in the research world quite a bit. For anybody who's interested in the topic, probably the best paper to go to is from 2018 from Pickering and Kylie. The title of it is, do non-responders to exercise exist and if so, what should we do about this? It's like non-responders. It's perfect. It was a great, I remember reading it when it first came out, we circulated at a round-eyed group and a lot of the discussion there and in that kind of field informed a lot of the discussion that you guys heard from us this weekend, as far as how we presented it to you. Definitely, influence our thoughts on the matter. As it turns out, this concept of non-response to exercise is not really defined all that well because the idea is there are a whole host of different adaptations that you can get out of exercise. And the idea of non-response just means that there's no change in any measurable, physiologic variable whatsoever, which is pretty unlikely. In fact, they make a case and we agree with it that it doesn't basically happen again in living humans. As we made the case, during the seminar, we said, if you're alive, you have the capacity to adapt in some capacity. That means that there may be some variables that you adapt more to in a given program and some less and somebody else might respond in a different pattern across those kind of physiologic variables. They make the case that we should differentiate or not get away from using the term non-responder altogether and focus more on the term, did not respond, IE, to that particular program, which is exactly what we discussed this weekend, rather than labeling somebody OU or a non-responder like you're incapable of adapting. Rather, this program wasn't the right one for you and rather we need to find the right dose and formulation of stimulus for you. The other interesting aspect of this is they cite a whole bunch of the research in this realm and they found that rates of apparent non-response to exercise go down, meaning we see more and more people respond. The longer a study goes, so if you keep people training for longer, eventually you see some response, additionally with higher doses of training, which is exactly what we talked about this weekend, higher volumes or in some contexts, higher frequencies. So there are studies of people training twice a week and you see a parent, low responders in that study and they bump them up to four times a week and suddenly you see training responses, so increasing the dose of exercise. And then the other one is interesting and it pertains more to study methodology. It has to do with how many variables they actually measure. So if all you measure is like one RM strength, for example, then there may be more apparent non-responders compared to if you measured strength outcomes, hypertrophy outcomes, maybe body composition changes, maybe resting heart rate changes, maybe blood pressure, maybe blood lipids, the more things you measure, the more likely you are to actually end up detecting some adaptive response to exercise. So that part is like almost a study methodology issue where you can have higher rates of kind of apparent non-response. If you don't look at enough variables of adaptation that people can possibly respond to exercise with. So all of this stuff heavily informed the discussion that you guys heard during the lecture this weekend and the idea that if you're alive you can adapt in some capacity to something and we are job the coaches job is to find the right dose and formulation of exercise to help you generate their response that you're looking for. Yeah, do you imagine a situation where somebody told you that you were a non-responder to exercise? And then or like you had been training for a while, let's say like a year, and no program that you had done had worked well for you. Everything you felt like, at least relative to your expectations and then maybe the people who you were working out with or training with, they all did much better than you. So you were on the low and the accountant end of the scale, again, President Company excluded. Like what kind of psychological warfare would you have to endure to just persevere and then be like, it's going to be okay, I'm going to find this program, I'm going to identify this thing. But that happens all the time in sport where people don't do well at their self-selected sport or their second sport that they got exposed to or the third sport. But they keep trying different things and find the thing that they excel with. And I think that's how I view training. It's like even if you've been on five, six, whatever, different programs before and not done that well. My role is a coach is to identify the thing where things that allow you to develop yourself to your maximum potential. That's what I'm here for, ideally. So the idea that fitting people into this rigid like it's got to be this program, why does this program work all the time, for example, or because it's working the past with other people I've coached or it's my preference. Those things are holding coaches back. Those things are holding their clients back. And so the idea would be more malleable, be more open to trying different things. You're trying to find, again, the right dose, the right formulation and anything that stands in your way of doing that is basically limitation. And that could may include being told or sort of condition to be like, well, you're just not going to respond well. You're a woman. You can't respond well to training. Right? And it's like, what does that do at a society level? But that's for another YouTube video. So don't hate me in the comments. You'll hear similar discussions come up when people talk about weight loss and diets. There's discussion, you'll hear doctors, for example, or coaches say, this individual failed this diet, or they failed so many number of diets, or in medicine you'll hear people say, this patient, quote, failed physical therapy. I'd always correct that kind of language when we're talking about it because none of these things are like one monolithic intervention that we can do to people. And the person didn't fail the diet. That dietary approach did not work for them. And there is an approach that we can find, keep experimenting until we find something that worked similarly, the specific approach that was provided by the specific physical therapists that they saw may not have worked well for them. You don't know what the dose of exercise was, the formulation, maybe all they did was they went in and they got passive east in for the whole 12 weeks of their rehab. No shit, they didn't get better. Right? Because that doesn't work unless they were going to get better on their own anyway. So they didn't fail that physical therapy, that physical therapist, or more arguably failed the patient and we need to find a better way to get them to adapt. In that situation, in the same way, somebody training for performance needs to find the right formulation to adapt. Same way, somebody trying to find the right diet for weight loss, needs to find the right dietary setup that's going to work for them to let them achieve their goals. Yeah. The 35-year-old male failed exercise. Right. Wait, what? Yeah. Okay.

Music Hey everyone, welcome back to the Barbell Medicine YouTube channel. What are we talking about today? Hurnie is. Let's not waste any time. Let's dig into this. Music Hurnia is when an organ or part of an organ or tissue abnormally protrudes through the wall of the cavity that's normally contained in such as when a loop of bowel gets pushed through a weed point in the abdominal wall fascia. This weed point creates a defect in the fascia which is basically a band or sheet of connected tissue. It's primarily collagen that's beneath the skin and attaches stabilizes and closes and separates muscles and other organs. Alright next up how are hernias named and the reason I wanted to talk about this is because people read this diagnosis and they're like well what the heck does that mean? So hernias are typically classified by location and or cause. For example, hernias that develop from a prior surgical incision are called incisional hernias. Those that don't result from a surgical incision are called primary or acquired hernias. They're also named by location. So ventral hernias which occur anteriorly on the ventral side of the body can be epigastric in the epigastric area or umbilical in the region of the umbilicus et cetera. Similarly, growing hernias occur in the lower region of the abdomen, the groin where the thigh beats the hip and there are two major types femoral and ingwinnell. Ingwinnell occurs along the ingwinnell canal typically above. Whereas femoral hernias occur typically below the ingwinnell canal. There are many other types of hernias, but we're going to focus on ingwinnell hernias in this video. What other thing to say, sometimes the complications also make their way into the naming of the hernias or you might hear people describe these different terms such as reducible basically meaning you can push the hernia back in through the defect in the cavity that it normally was enclosed in or an incarcerated hernia which basically means the hernias trapped and it cannot be reduced which causes reduced blood flow. Also strangulation which basically leads to uh ischemia or lack of blood flow and necrosis or death of the contents of the hernia. Next up, who gets an ingwinnell hernia? So this is super common approximately 5 million Americans about 5% of the population have hernia. The majority of these hernias are located in the groin 96% of them are ingwinnell hernias which again is a subject of this video. This typically results in about 700,000 surgical repairs each year in the United States and it's the third most common reason for people to go see their doctor. Alright next up, getting to the meat of this, how do you know if you have hernia? So about 2-3rd, 66% of hernias are symptomatic meaning that you're going to have a dull vague pain usually in the lower groin or lower abdomen region. On the other hand, if you have moderate to severe pain that comes on with the quickness, it still could be due to hernia but probably not just your run in the middle hernia but perhaps it's incarcerated or strangulated and that warns emergent sort of evaluation from a physician. If it comes on quickly and it's not due to hernia it could also be to stick to the torsion, epididomytois, hydroceal, varicocel or a bunch of other different medical conditions that again need to be worked up by a doctor. So if 2-3rds are symptomatic, that means that 1-3rd are asymptomatic or without symptoms but typically there's a bulge that is present and that you can see and that the physician will be able to see. Typically that will be reducible again that you can actually push the contents of the hernia back through the wall where it was herniated from. This is diagnosed via physical examination and physical exams actually pretty good at picking this stuff up so it's 75% sensitive and 96% specific. Those are pretty good odds. Typically you have the patient standing an actively coughing or doing a valsalvo maneuver and should see a bulge above or below the inclinal ligament crease. So above's typically an inclinal hernia and below is typically a femoral hernia. Now the real reason why you all are here, what causes hernia. So there are a handful of things that we have a high degree of evidence for. So thing 1 inheritance. So basically give a first degree relative that's been diagnosed with an inclinal hernia that increases the likelihood that you will get an inclinal hernia. Gender also we've kind of discussed this before. This is way more common in men about eight times than there 20 times more likely to need a surgical repair. Age also appears to be a risk factor for developing an inclinal hernia and there appears to be this like buy modal distribution meaning there's one signal one peak very early age about five years old and then the next biggest peak occurs. When individuals are much older 60 to 74 years old now it does appear to increase over time as individuals get older and older. So individuals that are 24 to 39 tend to have a lower risk than individuals who are 40 to 59 and that again keeps increasing 60 to 74 and 75 plus other things that increase risk of inclinal hernias that we have high levels of evidence for. So connective tissue disorders typically that are inherited if you have prostate surgery history specifically prostatectomy so removal of the prostate either complete or partial. And there are handful of things that may increase risk although we don't really have great evidence for them so race may play a role. Inglinal hernias are significantly less common among black adults. For example chronic constipation may also increase inglinal herniar risk although the date is not great. Now a few of you are probably scratching your head thinking hey didn't you miss a few things like obesity don't individuals with obesity have higher risks of inclinal herniad development because we know that obesity or excess atopacity tends to be a risk factor for many different things. overweight or who are obese tend to have lower incidences of inginal hernias another thing you'll notice that I didn't say increased risk of inginal hernia is tobacco use again if you asked doctors just in the street hey what increases risk of any disease most of the time they're going to say excess atopose tissue or obesity and then the next thing is going to be smoking or some some of that now let's get to the good stuff the real reason that you guys are here at the barbell minutes and YouTube channels because you want to know does lifting actually increase the risk of inginal hernia development you know that you're going to get a hernia or maybe that was just my family but that is a question that we get all the time and so I dug into the research and there's a few different lines is highly unlikely that the development of a dominal wall hernia can be attributable to a single strenuous event and effectively I'll read the exact quotation we conclude that we are unable to find increases your risk so what we have is secondly, you might think that have some some more头 and moreakes rather than very difficult understanding. heavy lifting, particularly because you have to hold your breath because you're doing a Valsalva maneuver. So the Valsalva maneuvers when you fill up your lungs with air so the lungs expand the diaphragm goes down and impart some pressure in the abdominal cavity, because the diaphragm goes down. You're contracting your abs which limits how far the internal organs can go forward so you create increased inter-abdominal pressure. You also also get increased intra-therasic pressure because you're not letting that air escape, basically you've closed your glottis so you have increased intra-therasic pressure appear and increased intra-abdominal pressure down there. The idea is all this increase in pressure is going to keep cumulatively cause a defect in the fascia, a defect in the musculature, something like that that's going to cause you to have a hernia. So let's take a look at what the data says. It doesn't appear that cumulative intra-abdominal pressure increases the risk of developing an inclinal hernia. So to better answer this question we can look at this Danish study where they took 18,000 men followed them for about 18 years to see if there was any correlation between the hours spent per day standing, walking or lifting loads greater than 20 kilos. Now if there was an issue with this cumulative intra-abdominal stress what you'd expect to see is way greater incidents of enguinal hernias in those who spent the most time lifting loads greater than 20 kilos. Right? However there was no significant difference in enguinal hernia cases between those who lifted the most wheat per day and those who didn't lift at all. In fact the only significant relationship that was found was that those individuals who were standing for greater than six hours per day had a 45% higher risk of having to have surgery to repair an enguinal hernia than those who were standing for less than four hours per day. But there was no association found with a amount of load lifted or frequency of load lifted. So that all suggests that lifting probably doesn't increase the risk of developing hernia. Rather the things that we referred to earlier, particularly the things that have high levels of evidence that they increase enguinal herniarisc. So inheritance, that familial predisposition, sex, so again males tend to have a much higher risk of developing enguinal hernia than women do age, that by-modeled distribution that we talked about, connect of tissue disorders, surgical histories, specifically prostatectomy. Those things probably contribute much, much more than any sort of sort of lifting based risk. All right, so now we get to talk about treatment. If you have an enguinal hernia, what do? If you're concerned that you have a hernia based on symptoms and or the presence of a bulge, you should be evaluated by a physician for diagnosis and management. Go get a check-out. Don't listen to me here on the internet to diagnose you. But if you get diagnosed, what can you expect? So from a treatment standpoint, most enguinal hernias are symptomatic and the definitive cure for asymptomatic growing hernia is surgery. asymptomatic are minimally symptomatic, male and glinal hernia patients may choose to use this watchful weight in approach since the risk of hernia-related emergencies is relatively low. Now there are some risks, so like complications of the hernia, the symptoms could worsen and they may be in need for emergency surgery. But again, that's relatively low. So basically a shared decision between the physician and the patient based on preferences, risks, they'd individual case and all that sort of stuff should be undertaken. So if you do need surgery, a mesh repair is recommended as the first choice. And the surgery can be performed by a number of different ways, which depends on the surgeon, their expertise, the patient and hernia-related characteristics and complications, the anatomy, and also the resources. Right now, one standard repair technique for all growing hernias does not exist. All right, you just had hernia repair surgery and you're trying to get back to lifting what do. So unfortunately, most surgeons' recommendations for physical activity restrictions are not evidence-based and they have the potential to greatly affect physical activity participation in their patients. The existing data on inguinal hernia repair indicates that most activities can be resumed within three to five days for those undergoing elective and glinal hernia repair. And in fact, when you look at the 2018 International Guidelines for Hernia Management, they actually say a period of rest or a lifting restriction is not necessary after an inguinal hernia operation. Patients can do what they feel capable of doing. So your surgeon may give you different advice and it's up to you to advocate for your own help and ask questions as to why because there might have been a complication or particular procedure used that increases your risk and then also just be upfront about what's your plan and undoing and try to come up with this sort of shared decision making plan with them. But that's what the data says. That's what the current guidelines are. === FILE: Does Liposuction Make You Healthier？ [5xyPfHUIWoY].txt ===

Number seven is liposuction ever a good idea. And I think context for this question, you can view this question in a couple different contexts. One is in the context of our discussions all weekend here with respect to health. So I would kind of think back to when we talked about obesity and the situations where carrying excess body fat can be problematic. And in particular, we talked about how tight of a relationship there is with the abdominal waste or comforts and medical complications. And the reason why there's such a close relationship there is because that measurement reflects intrabdominal or what we call visceral body fat accumulation. Inside the abdomen, inside the organs, inside the liver, for example, which is different visceral body fat or addopose accumulation is a bit different than subcutaneous or body fat that accumulates under the skin. And so the one body fat or addoposes infiltrating your abdominal organs, your liver, your pancreas, things like that. That's when we see big time increases in diabetes risk, cardiovascular risk, things like that. Whereas liposuction as a treatment primarily removes subcutaneous body fat, not the condits inside, not the condits in the liver. So there's actually some data on this. There's a small study that I found while I was prepping for this where they took a group of women, some of whom had diabetes and some of whom did not all of whom had excess body fat and they performed serial, large volume liposuction. Removing large amounts of subcutaneous body fat. You're going to say something? What did you just move it? Put it someplace else? Yeah. Now, why you would do that? Okay. And they severely removed this subcutaneous body fat. And then when they looked at how they did afterwards, they did find that their waste circumference went down as a result of removing body fat. Obviously, their leptin levels went down and leptin is a hormone that is high when you have lots of body fat and low when you have less body fat. So that obviously went down. That all makes sense. When they measured their actual levels of insulin resistance and their cardiovascular risk factors, things like blood lipids and things like that, there's no change. So from a health standpoint, I do not have a good case to make for liposuction. If you say, is it ever a good idea? Well, that's strictly up to you from a cosmetic standpoint, you know, at that point. I would not recommend it for medical benefits. If there is excess body fat that needs to be dealt with, invasively or surgically, and there are medical issues going on, or even if there aren't, and you meet criteria based on the criteria that we talked about. Today, I would say, real bariatric surgery is far more beneficial from a health standpoint than liposuction would be because we talked about how the long term 20, 25-year follow-up of patients who get bariatric surgery. They have much greater and much more sustained weight loss and health benefits. You can cure diabetes in a couple days after getting bariatric surgery. It just goes away, which is pretty wild. Whereas liposuction does not have any of those benefits outside of cosmetic effects. I think if for whatever reason you're getting like this rural liposuction, don't think that's that liposuction. Maybe that, or if the liposuction would somehow improve at hearings to other lifestyle changes, if you felt like, I'm going to pay for this procedure from an aesthetic standpoint, or because I feel like it's going to jump start my progress. That's really going to help keep me motivated and it does, as far as improving adherence to a health promoting dietary pattern and exercise like cool. But if you're just like moving it around, you know, from like front to back, I don't know that that's the move.

=== FILE: Does YOUR Anatomy Predict Your Lifting Technique？ [-fU859dMat4].txt ===

A side from a lifters preferences and goals is there anything anatomical that a coach could look at to determine if a lifter would have an advantageous leverage for a specific squat or deadlift style. This is an interesting question. We've kind of answered something like this before on our YouTube channel. There are anthropometric features that I can look at and have in a guess. I can hazard a guess that somebody would prefer a particular style or maybe do better at a particular style, but I won't know until after they've exposed themselves to regular training over a long period of time. So if we're just talking about like, let's see how much you can lift today, I would expect somebody with very short arms, for example, relative to their torso and lower extremities to might pull, they might be a better sumo deadlifter, right? Then a conventional pull, it provided no other training has taken place. Somebody, for example, with really, really long femurs might do better with a low bar back squat, provided that they can rack the bar and a secure position. So that's just me thinking about all the folks that I've coached and trained throughout my career. That assumes no like the experience or training by that person prior to that test. So I would feel very, very uncomfortable predicting like what type of style somebody should adopt based on their anthropometric measurements, particularly without seeing them lift, over a long period of time. Whatever style you adopt today is likely to change over the course of your training career, based on changing leverages, preferences, skill development, and this things you unlock from exposing yourself to different training variations. And I think any sort of prediction I can make is just going to be weak as far as it's predictive power. Yeah, nothing that I can measure on the person when they first come in is going to outweigh the combination of subjective athlete feedback over time as they train and then objective performance metrics. So I don't think it's important to even attempt to predict certainly everybody would look at somebody who has gigantic long arms and say, oh, they're probably going to be a good deadlifter. Doesn't take a genius to recognize that in most people. But as far as saying, I'm going to force you to pull in a certain way because I think that you're built to pull this way. Meanwhile, they may be subjectively telling me, I really don't like this. This is not comfortable. Okay, I need to recognize that and accommodate for it in the coaching or the programming plan. So subjective athlete feedback and objective performance metrics over, as you said, a long period of time are going to what will guide those decisions much more so than just looking at somebody and saying, yeah, I'm going to fit you in this box. Right. And that's even better than any sort of screening test that we could do. Okay, if you place your toe six inches from the wall while you're kneeling and try to shove your knee to the wall, can you touch your knee to the wall? Ooh, you're missing some ankle door selection. In that case, we needed to adopt this particular squat style, both the bar placement, death, tempo, etc. Otherwise, you're at increased risk of injury. So not only did I know Cibo, the crap out of that person, one that's all made up gibberish. Made up gibberish because it has never been validated in any particular type of controlled setting. And about a who uses that type of test to predict squat stance, style, etc. Whenever may occasionally get right, get that right, or at least to the extent that can be right. And then there's subsequently just self-congratulation. And like, yeah, see I did it. So the point then becomes, why would you try to do this predict via anthropometry or why would you screen somebody for if they can do an exercise without having them do the exercise? Is that suggest that the exercise itself, doing the movement itself is so risky, right? Or it's so important to get it right the first time that you have to do something beforehand. And none of that is true. Exercise, even resistance training, even heavy resistance training, even heavy resistance training with bad form, whatever that means, is very, very safe, very, very safe. Injury rate, injury incidence is very low. The duration of symptoms for people who do get injured is very, very short and self-limited. It's catastrophic injuries. In general, don't happen unless you happen to be a young kid, smash yourself over the head with the plate that you dropped. That happens sometimes. But so what I'm getting at is like, why would we do this? How many times do you screen somebody prior to exercise? Or they're like physical movement? Yeah, never. Yeah. Nope.
