That's what's causing this. And until I get that fixed, I'll never be whole. I'll never not have low back pain. Could hold you back in a long term. Okay. So since there are biological and psychological inputs that drive this pain experience, those are the targets we should actually address. So let's talk about those. Biological, let's talk about exercise. So I started this earlier on saying that one of the reasons why people, one of the biological causes where people can have this most common type of low back pain is when the training stress or work low outstrips what somebody has prepared for. It's increases too quickly and too much. So preparing for the demands via training that gradually increases over time is how we would address this. So we would start people with something that they can tolerate today right now. And then gradually increase that stress over time. I know this is just shocking. But this is also how we would start treating this type of low back pain. So let's say somebody tried the new trap-bar deadlift test. And they said that they had back pain after that. That's a traumatic experience. They know they have to do this test to keep their job. Okay. And they did it once and then they had back pain afterwards. So like, look, I did the deadlift and then now my back hurts. And now you're telling me how to do it again anyway. So what we do in that situation were one, one biological cause for somebody who had back pain after that is if they've never deadlifted before. And now you put them into a competitive or testing situation. It's probably not the best way to do it. What we would rather have them do is be exposed to it under less challenging less challenging situation and gradually work them up to the test they're going to have to do. That's training over a longer period of time. That might mean starting with just the empty bar. In this case, after somebody already has pain, what we want to do is desensitize them. We want to reduce the threat. So they even see the trap bar. They say, look, no, I can't. They have PTSD. What I'd love to get them to do is do a trap bar deadlift from a reduced range of motion, maybe from a higher platform, right? Or if they were previously doing it with weight on the bar, do it with just the empty bar. Something where they could do the movement as close as possible to the movement that they're going to be asked to do, but that they're able to tolerate. We're going to try to desensitize them, reduce the threat, reduce the fear around that. Now, if they won't do it at all, we'll do something else. That's similar. We'll gradually have to move farther and farther away from what they need to prepare for, but we'd like to do what we'd like to do ideally is if somebody said, look, I hurt my back in the trap bar deadlift, what do you recommend I do? I think you should do the trap bar deadlift again. But at a more manageable load, whether that's total weight, total reps, sets, et cetera, the whole training load needs to be appropriate for what you can handle right now. And that got to be has to be gradually built up over time. Getting stronger over time is going to help the individual or you to be more tolerant of different stresses, particularly those around physical activity. It also helps build self-efficacy. If someone comes into me and says, I've back pain, I did it while I was doing the trap bar deadlift, for my new on-the-fysical fitness test. What do you recommend that I do? I say, look, I think you know, I'd ask them, what was your previous exercise history? And get that information and I'd say, I think you need to do the trap bar deadlift, in addition to these other exercises to get you fit fit for duty. And here's how I would do that. And you need to be in charge of this. Get the process of going through this sort of training-based rehabilitation build self-efficacy. You're the one who's responsible to get better. You don't need to come see me multiple times a week for an adjustment, for a massage, for a pep talk. Rather, I want to give you the power to manage this on your own. The last part of this with respect to exercise is a term we call auto-regulation, which is a fancy way of saying adjusting things based on the amount of resources that you have. So imagine a situation where you're super, you're sleep deprived, or you're really sad, or really upset, or you're really hungry, or something that ultimately puts you not at your best. Relationships stress, occupational stress, something like that. And it's really bad. And you're not able to perform up to your best. You're not able to tolerate as much training stress as you would when everything's going your way. So our recommendation would be instead of just pushing through it because pain don't hurt and pain is weakness leaving the body is to have a sort of stop gap in place where you don't end up pushing too far too quickly. So easy ways to do this. Most of your training sessions that you're doing at the gym, because all of you are now going to be engaging in your resistance training. Most of your training sessions, if you were going to rate how hard they were, how fatigued you were at the end of the training session, should be about six to eight on a scale of one to ten. If at the end of every training session you're like that was a ten, I've never been more tired than this after exercise. This is it. That's probably too much for you. It's probably too much. On the other hand, if it's a two, you're like, I'm fine. It's probably not enough to encourage change. Six to eight's kind of that sweet spot. So during periods of high stress right from whatever reason, keeping it in that ballpark is going to kind of keep you safe from a training perspective. Your unlike you're not going to be able to ideally push yourself into that, hey, I did too much for the available for what I was prepared for. So that's from an exercise standpoint, what should we do? From a psychosocial standpoint, the first thing we can do, and what we're trying to do right now is education. But what pain is, why people have pain? There's no pain generator. We talked about that. Pain doesn't necessarily equal harm. Like harm to the tissue or tissue damage. If you know anybody who's been to war and maybe still has shrapnel in their body, that's the definition of tissue damage. And they may or may not have pain from that, for example. And during this educational period, we'd also like to give you tools so that you can self-manage, whether that's exercise advice, whether that's managing your training, whether that's new information about just straight up what doesn't cause pain, all of these things can be helpful. So that can be super useful. And then finally, from a social standpoint, I'd really like to encourage all of us, everybody in this room, to watch our words and actions, what we say to each other and how we act towards each other with respect to pain. So if you happen to see a woman or a man fall off a pull-up structure onto the ground, get up and walk away just fine, just go on living your life. You don't need to go over and ask them if they have back pain now, tell them to sit down and then go on WebMD. They're probably going to be fine. If you have low back pain, we would highly encourage you to stay calm, to not catastrophize it and say, oh, this is probably something traumatic, because it's probably not. And then to try to talk yourself into self-managing. If you need a professional counsel, we'd like you to see a health care provider who's trained up on this stuff. And then when we're talking to friends about what causes pain. Somebody says, oh, yeah, it's my bad disk. That's what's causing the pain. If you feel comfortable talking to them about this stuff, you might try to engage in a conversation where you can provide them more information. If it's your Uber driver, maybe you say, oh, yeah, that's wild. And then don't say anything else. It's a long drive from here to bar still as I found out yesterday. All right. So let's wrap this up with some take-home messages. Take-home's here. Pain is an experience that we have in order to try to protect ourselves from our perceived threat. The threat is a combination of many different factors. It's not just one thing. Anything that increases that threat is going to increase, has the likelihood of increasing our pain. So whether that's fear, whether that's not knowing what's going on. All right. Or learned experience. All of those things can increase pain. Most well-back pain is not due to something serious like a fracture, mass, or infection. Most of it resolves in four to six weeks on its own. We covered, I think, in some pretty good detail that it's mostly not, it's most likely not related to some anatomical issue like a disc, the set joint or anything like that. To treat and reduce the risk of low back pain, we need to exercise and build tolerance and reduce sensitivity. Motion is lotion. So if you're having low back pain, the worst thing you can do is be sedentary, not exercise. The best thing you could do is try to do an exercise that's very similar to what you were doing when you got hurt. Tensual with reduced load. Potentially with the reduced range of motion. Potentially with an altered tempo. The idea is again, not to be scared of it and to desensitize you to to that exercise, to that motion. It's all about violation expectation in that instance, meaning that you expect yourself to have pain when you bend over, for example, if you hurt yourself deadlifting. Well, we'd like to prove to you that that's not always going to be the case. And if we can violate that expectation, we can put you on this path towards improving self-efficacy and you'd be able to self-manage this on your own. And then finally, ideally, you would all be part of a social change revolution to change the way that we all think and talk about back pain and society. Because we can't do this on our own. There's only two of us, but as we get to kind of spread this message to folks, the idea is that this becomes less and less of a problem. I thank you for your time, Luke and I now.

It's not bad, it just wasn't complete and what I'd rather do is try to give you guys my presentation on injury risk and risk reduction in powerlifting. So we'll put my PowerPoint up here and you guys can follow along. The links to all the studies that I cite in here will be in the description below and as well as some other ways that you can keep up with latest barbell medicine content. So let's start out here. So let's establish our objectives for this presentation. One, we want to define what an injury is. We want to characterize the injury risk in powerlifting, discuss strategies for injury risk reduction and discuss strategies for injury management. We're going to try to jam this in to about 20 minutes. I had an hour to present at the European Powerlifting Conference and there were some questions that kind of ate up some time. But if we can jam this into 20 minutes, I think that'll be good. And then you guys can hear from the rest of the speakers. So disclaimers, this is not medical advice. I am not your doctor. You should seek professional evaluation and we have a great pain rehab, consult service that we offer through barbell medicine. So I own that company. That's my conflict of interest. So the first part we should start with is what is an injury and the very beginning, why do these definitions even matter? How you define an injury determines its prevalence, meaning that when you try to study this in the research, if you change the definition, you can actually change the prevalence or how many injuries you see in a population. So prevalence is a scientific term for the number of active cases present in a population at a given time. So to highlight this, we'll look at a study from Bar at Al. They studied 176 volleyball players during the 2001 World Tour to the eight-week competition. They used two different definitions to try to compare the prevalence of injuries in this athletic population. So definition one, they used what's called a time loss definition for injury, which is any physical complaint that resulted in time loss from competition or training. Definition number two was based purely on physical symptoms. So any physical complaint of pain sustained by the player during a volleyball match or training irrespective of the need for medical attention or time loss from volleyball activities or training. So using definition one, which was the time loss definition, 23 injuries were reported in these 176 volleyball players over the eight weeks. The majority were mild and the only missed one to three days. Using definition number two, which was again, the physical symptoms irrespective of time loss or actual need for medical evaluation, there were 54 injuries. So over double the amount of injuries that were reported. However, 98% of women and 100% of men did not miss any play in time. Meaning that these people had physical complaints. However, they didn't actually need to change their training or their competition schedule. So the real question is, is that an injury? Is that a useful definition? What do we need to actually have criteria wise for something to be meaningfully called an injury? So to help guide us, I think if we go back into the history of where the word injury even comes from, that might actually help us determine where to go next. The word injuries actually derived from a 14th century Latin word injury, which breaks down into not right. So in meaning not and then juror meaning right or loss of not right. So the earliest history of this being written down or recorded probably goes to Homer. A Greek author in the 8th century BC book, The Iliad. He describes a crash of a humiloce of Corinth during a chariot race. And he says that he has Rexus of the skin, which is a discontinuity in the skin. The injuries also described in the book of Genesis in the Bible when Jacob's thigh was out of joint secondary to wrestling. However, it's interesting that neither then nor seemingly now do we have a unified definition for what an injury actually is. Because neither of those texts actually characterized what was being experienced by the individual. And thus the reader's left wanting more details was umilose in pain after being thrown from his chariot was Jacob able to walk it off after his thigh was out of place. Hard to say and again, we don't know that from either of those texts. And so it's just interesting that that's where it came from. We still didn't really have a good characterization of what it actually meant to have a quote unquote injury. So really from then until about 2006, we didn't have a unified definition for sports injury. So enter the first World Congress on Sports injury, which was held by FIFA in 2006. Basically they came up with different types of injuries that fell under the umbrella term of sports injuries. So there could be a physical complaint injury, which was any physical complaint sustained by a player resulting from a football match or football training irrespective of the need for medical attention or time loss from football activities. There was also a medical attention injury, which was any physical complaint requiring medical attention, a time loss injury, any physical complaint that resulted in time loss from training a competition. And then a non-fatal catastrophic injury. This was actually added a year later in 2007. This is a brain or spinal cord injury resulting in greater than 12 months of severe functional disability. So this was actually the first kind of consensus on this is what a sports injury is. However, this was just for the sport of soccer. And it hasn't been widely adopted in either the research literature or by other sports organizations. And so we still don't have this definition of. Here's what an injury is. Here are the criteria. And that really tends to influence the research. And unfortunately, it makes it harder to analyze and interpret these sorts of things. So we're going to get into it during this presentation and try to make sense of the data as it pertains to powerlifting. So unfortunately, these criteria have not been adopted by either the research or other sports organizations. And on the one hand, it's frustrating because that influences the actual research we have on injury prevalence in certain sports. On the other hand, it's kind of understandable because different sports are likely to have different injury criteria based on the needs of that sport. So for example, consider a gymnast and a figure skater suffer a wrist-sprayin during training. Does this constitute an injury in both athletes? Probably not the wrist-brayin only limits the gymnast likely whereas the same injury probably doesn't affect the figure skater. Although it might and in which case we could call that an injury. So just having these sort of physical complaints that maybe don't influence actual training or competition schedule, it'd be hard to say. And so you might need different criteria for each sport. Also perspective matters. And so it depends who you're asking what constitutes an injury. Are you asking the athlete? Are you asking the clinician or the coach? So actually this study was done by boiling at Al in 2018 where they interviewed athletes, coaches and physical therapists on what defines a sport injury. In general, athletes tend to focus on criteria specific to their own context. So a reduction in performance, having to change their plan, competition or training, stuff that immediately are directly affected them, conversely physical therapists tend to focus on things that they could find on physical exam. So weakness, instability, or pain. But not the change in training plan or competition schedule that seem to be more meaningful to the actual athlete. So the authors actually concluded that a sports injury should not be viewed as a health condition in itself, but should rather be viewed as an interaction between physical damage and contextual factors. So one of the hardest things I had to do for this presentation was actually created definition of injury. We propose a definition for injury that we're currently using in a prospective trial on about 500 individuals participating in powerlifting training. This is a headed up by Dr. Michael Ray and their collecting data right now. So the Barbell Medicine definition for injury is any complaint that causes a reduction in sports performance, secondary to training or competition. That's criteria one. Criteria number two is pain or discomfort as rated by the athlete and or objective neurological deficits that includes cognitive deficits as well that might occur from like a post-concussive syndrome or something like that that are experienced during or secondary to sports training and or competition. And in addition, any use of over the counter or prescribed anal gs to reduce pain or discomfort during training or competitive sport would also fit this criteria. And then finally criteria number three, training or competition schedule is modified significantly to reflect a changing goals or prioritized outcomes secondary to points one and two. In this case, the term modified refers to the alteration of single competition or at least one weeks worth of training. For example, I power lifter withdraws from a full power me due to knee pain and reduced performance in the squat and or deadlift and now focuses on a bench only meat. So that would qualify for the competition schedule being modified. So after these criteria have been set forth, we also wanted to classify sports injuries as and there's a variety. So what we did is we came up with different sort of time periods that reflects the severity of the injury based on our definition. So a minor injury one to 14 days is the duration, a moderate injury, 15 to 30 days and a serious injury greater than 30 days. And we picked these words carefully because language matters. Other classification systems and then in studies where they do actually define how they characterized an injury will say things like severe or catastrophic injuries for things that last longer than 30 days. And that may actually impair not only the current sort of symptoms that may make it worse and it may actually impair the rehab and recovery process. It should be noted that injuries are complex and it may be possible for an athlete to meet points one and three without point two, but this should necessarily negate a classification of a sports injury that person would still likely qualify. Even if they don't have a pain or discomfort or an objective neurological deficit although most of the time they likely will. So one should note that there's no requirement for tissue damage. And the best way to talk about this is actually by using an example so we'll use delayed onset muscle soreness which is known as doms. Using these criteria, routine delayed onset muscle soreness or doms would not be considered an injury. While doms can produce short-term reduction in performance as well as mild pain or discomfort, it does not typically require substantial prolong modification of the training or competition schedule unless it is very severe. In that case when doms is very severe, it would qualify as an injury but your regular soreness would not. One thing you'll notice about our definition of injury is that it's lacking any sort of requirement for tissue damage. That's because tissue damage doesn't reliably correlate to pain or dysfunction and so that's why we left it out and we'll go through this a little bit further. But before we do that, this is really one of the problems in the FIFA definition that was put forth in 2006. Each one of those items, each one of the types of injuries that they proposed, the categories was based around this sort of physical complaint like it's all biological or it's all tissue damage. But as we'll see that doesn't seem to be the case. So speaking of tissue damage, one problem with the finding injury is that there's no real distinction between disease and injury. Some scientists tend to hold the idea that injury describes damage to the body due to sudden energy changes, whereas a disease makes its presence known over longer periods of time. But this presents a number of problems with respect to injuries and pain that aren't reliably correlated to tissue damage, such as non-specific low back pain and some causes of tendonopathy, tendonopathy being an umbrella term that refers to tendon pain without specifying an underlying pathology. So we're going to make the case that tissue damage is not the same as pain. The biomedical understanding of pain is problematic. It inaccurately endorses a linear relationship between noxious stimuli and pain and is often dualist or reductionist. From a reductionist perspective, pain is often considered to be in the brain. The biocycossocial conceptualization of pain suggests biological, psychological and social factors all being integrated together at the brain, body and the environmental level. The person's experience of that integration. However, biology does not equal pain on its own. So let's go through some examples here. So for example, 21 major league baseball players received serial shoulder MRIs prior to each season for 10 years. All the pictures had some sort of tear or defect observed on MRI. 11 showed a rotator cuff tear. 9 showed an articular surface tear of the superspinatus tendon and 2 showed full thickness rotator cuff tears. Interestingly, all of the pictures were asymptomatic. They had no symptoms. Furthermore, those with evidence of a rotator cuff tear pitched over a thousand career anines were as those without evidence of a rotator cuff tear pitched less anines. About 729, this is from Lezniak 2013. The authors actually said there are no statistically significant findings between any single preseason MRI finding and subsequent time on the disabled list. A moving to a basketball, the reported prevalence of meniscal and articular cartilage abnormalities based on MRI findings are about 20 and 50 percent in asymptomatic, collegiate and professional basketball players respectively. So collegiate basketball players, about 20 percent, prevalence of meniscal and articular cartilage a damage on MRI whereas professional ball players is about 50 percent. They further reviewed MRIs on both knees of 14 NBA players who at the time of MRI demonstrated a normal physical exam meaning there were no deficiencies found on clinical exam. They had full range of motion, no joint swelling or tenderness, no ligamentes into stability, etc. All the players who had MRIs of their knees had at least one imaging abnormality. Only 3 knees total, 10 percent of the sample had no evidence of abnormality. Papas at al found a high prevalence of both patella and quadriceps tendon abnormalities in a review of 24 D1 college basketball players, a specifically 83 percent of women and 90 percent of men showed abnormal patella tendon findings. Additionally 75 percent of women and 90 percent of men showed abnormal quadriceps tendon findings. And again, I cannot stress this enough. All of these individuals we just talked about with all these imaging abnormalities were asymptomatic at the time of imaging asymptomatic. And so the reasons for this are numerous here are two potential ways to understand this. One, the tissue damage, quote unquote, may be adaptive. For example, when researchers compare the thickness of ACL and PCL which are ligaments in the knee in high level weight lifters versus sedentary controls, they found that weight lifters had much larger ACLs and PCLs. On average, weight lifters ACL were approximately 78 percent larger than those of their age match controls. Further, increasing the cross-sectional area, of those crucial ligaments, the ACL and the PCL could represent one way of reducing injury risk based on the current evidence of modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for a knee injury. Another issue with just trying to connect tissue damage that's diagnosed via imaging is that this may not be reliably diagnosed to begin with. So MRIs, while useful in many cases, are probably not as reliable as the public and some doctors think. So this is one of my favorite studies by Herzog in 2016. They sent the 63-year-old woman with back pain and sciatica to 10 different MRI facilities each who had a different radiologist who generated a different report. The 10 different radiologists generated 49 different findings in total, 16 of which were unique and not a single finding was found in all 10 reports. On average, each radiologist made about a dozen errors, either false positives or false negatives. Again, we hold MRIs up to be this whole eGrail for diagnosing tissue damage, but it doesn't appear to be as reliable some of the time. And then, again, people can have MRI abnormalities and still compete at a very high level. So, again, imaging abnormalities might be an artifact of improper reading or improper interpretation based on the actual radiologist report or maybe adaptive or it might just be a twa at a time-wasted on useless detail. It might not mean anything with respect to injury or pain and that kind of comports with our more complex model, the biosecoces social model of forepain that you hear us talk about. So, much, so the TLDR is super hard to define an injury, but how we define an injury actually matters. So, again, it cannot be stated enough that tissue damage does not reliably correlate to pain. You can have observable defects or abnormalities on imaging and that not be tied to pain or dysfunction. And so, thinking of everything is just related to the biology or the anatomy, that's very reductionist and we don't want to do that. And so, by the same token, pain does not necessarily mean harm. With that in mind, imaging should always be interpreted in the clinical context. In other words, it's not a finding a lesson connects in some way to a person's case. Just going in to have an MRI to check things out is likely a bad idea because you can find a host of abnormalities that otherwise wouldn't cause you any sort of issue unless you knew about it. So, do you want to know? It depends. The clinical context is important. So, now that we have a better idea of what an injury actually is and the problems with defining injuries, and then also tissue damage, let's talk about injury risk in power lifting. But, present, we have about eight studies that look specifically at the injury risk in power lifting and I've linked them all in the description below. The range of findings is between one to four injuries per thousand participation hours or about one to two injuries per athlete per year. This is similar across all barbell sports such as weightlifting and crossfit. The other hand, bodybuilding is slightly lower and strongman and highland games are slightly higher, although admittedly there are very few studies looking at strongman and highland games, athletes, injury rates. So, while the rate actually seems to be pretty low for power lifting injuries, the prevalence or number of total cases in a population can actually be high depending on how you define it. So, there's a 2018 study by a strong back at Al, they did it on sub elite Swedish power lifters. They basically took the people who were just below that elite cutoff based on a Wilkes score and then gave them a survey, asked them about injuries and certain training and lifestyle habits. They found that 90 of 104 responders either had a current injury or an injury in the past 12 months. While the store is out to be about 3.9 injuries per thousand participation hours as far as a rate is concerned, the overall prevalence was quite high. However, this prevalence is significantly impacted by the definition that they use. In this study, they decided that an injury was defined as a condition of pain or impairment of bodily function that affected a power lifters training. For example, 73 individuals reported a current injury, but only 40 actually changed their training by reducing volume or intensity. Conversely, about 12 people decided to increase their emphasis on technique, seven emphasized their warm-up does this constitute a meaningful change for those that emphasize their technique or their warm-up? Probably not. Maybe the 40 individuals who reported changing their volume or intensity actually had an injury whereas the other folks probably not if they didn't actually have to modify their training meaningfully. Another interesting thing is that the symptoms tend to be relatively short-lived, the average duration of injury in this study and the other studies that actually report a duration is less than two weeks. So, it's not like you're building towards this catastrophic injury. You know, all this tissue damage has to build up and then boom, you blow up in your out for months that appears to be less than two weeks. So, again, the injury rates relatively low and comparable to other non-contact sports and then the duration of symptoms tends to be relatively low as well. Another problem with the study is that it was retrospective. It asked athletes to recall self-reporting injuries over the past year. Recall bias is super common in these types of studies as participants may not remember previous events or experiences accurately and they might emit details. Additionally, the accuracy and number of memories recalled may be influenced by the events and the experiences themselves, aka in this case, the injury. Finally, the validity of a recalling an injury and retrospective injury studies has been shown to be very low even when assessed by medical professionals. We prefer to do a prospective study, which is what we're actually doing on our current study. So, the question we have is, is powerlifting safe? It appears to be relatively safe. One of four injuries per thousand participation hours, which is similar to other non-contact sports. So, for example, a prospective study of injuries in about 300 elites, we just track and feel athletes show that they had an injury rate of about 3.57 injuries per thousand participation hours. Interestingly, walk in in cycling are not purely benign either. Walking, for instance, has an injury rate as high as 1.2 injuries per thousand participation hours. cycling on the other hand has an injury rate around 2 injuries per thousand participation hours. When you compare this to popular sports, context sports, like American football and wrestling, American football has got an injury rate of 9.6 injuries per thousand participation hours and wrestling has an injury rate of 5.7 injuries per thousand participation hours according to a study by Hootman at Allen 2007. Sports like soccer, rugby and cricket all have these massively inflated injury rates as well, 15 to 81 injuries per thousand participation hours. So, comparatively powerlifting is pretty safe. So, the question then becomes, is it worth the risk? And I think if we turn to Nietzsche and one of the greatest rappers of the early 2000s DMX, we can get some insight on this. Nietzsche is a German philosopher and former soccer player and he's known for this phrase, the man who's the soccer player, he's a bi-fi-mediate and the stuff. DMX also said in his 1998 hit single slip-in. So, if you find meaning in the suffering from powerlifting, it's worth it. Up next, let's discuss some strategies for injury risk reduction. So, intrinsic factors are things like gender, competitive standard, so are you elite, are you novice, bodyweight age, load lift, some of these things are modifiable, some of these things are non-modifiable. So, we'll talk about gender here. First, where differences were observed, women actually tend to have a slightly lower injury rate in barbell sports compared to men, 1.3 injuries per lifter per year, compared to 2.1 injuries per lifter per year, and this was in two separate studies. Higher rate of knee injuries than men, however, which actually comports with other existing data we have on knee injury incidents in women in sports, but that's for a whole another video because the risk factors there probably are not just related to their gender. Moving on, competitive So, two studies actually investigated this. They compared elite level, international level competitors to non-alite or national level weight lifters. Elite lifters actually had a lower injury rate, 3.6 injuries per thousand participation hours versus 5.8 injuries per thousand participation hours for the non-alite weight lifters. Another study by Rasky at our reported 2.6 injuries per thousand participation hours in the elite group and 2.9 injuries per thousand participation hours in the non-alite weight lifting group. So getting more advanced in sport doesn't appear to confer additional risk. In fact, it may be a protective and one of the mechanisms here might be just building up this tolerance to train and the adaptive changes in all of the tissues and metabolic systems and the sort of physiology of the lifter to tolerate the type of training needed to perform at that high level. As far as body weight is concerned, there's actually no data on power of senior weight lifting and body weight and how it correlates to injury risk. However, there was a single study that was performed on strong man athletes and reported that heavyweight athletes, those who were greater than 231 pounds or 105 kilos, had more injuries than lightweight competitors, those who weighed less than 105 kilos. Basically, the difference is very small, however. Zero point five injuries per thousand participation hours for the heavyweight lifters compared to 0.3 injuries per thousand participation hours for the lightweight lifters. With respect to age, again, there's no data on power lifting and weight lifting. There's a study on strong man athletes that reported fewer injuries and athletes over the age of 30 compared to those under the age of 30. But again, this difference is pretty small. So point three injuries in the people over the age of 30 per thousand participation hours compared to 0.5 injuries in those under the age of 30 per thousand participation hours. With respect to the load being lifted, it in power lifting strong back showed that hitting a personal best was weekly correlated with reporting a current injury and had an odds ratio of 1.02. Now, this is important. An odds ratio isn't as statistical measure used to determine how strongly two events are correlated to each other. So an odds ratio of one suggests that two events are independent of one another, whereas a number higher or lower than one suggests a positive or negative correlation respectively. The further the number is away from one, the stronger the correlation. Importantly, correlation cannot prove causation. So in this case, the odds ratio of 1.02 is extremely small, perhaps meaningless or even artifact increase in risk. So we don't really have data of suggesting that increased load and power lifting increases the risk. And finally, this 2017 meta-analysis by Kio at Al, which, again, a link to the description below, is a meta-analysis on 20 studies, on injuries and barbell sports concluded, in general, intrinsic factors have relatively little effect on the injury epidemiology of the weight training sports. Moving on to extrinsic factors. So there are some extrinsic factors that don't have any influence. So things like competition rules, training or competitive environment or any specific equipment, actually increase injury risk. We don't have any data suggesting that that exists. That being said, we do have some data suggesting that extrinsic factors like the acute on chronic workload, stress levels, training level, and strength levels all can correlate to injury risk. For instance, acute to chronic workload, the load refers to the internal load. Internal load is the relative physiological and psychological stress imposed by external load. Ergo, the volume intensity rest periods the overall work on the individual as interpreted through their individual characteristics, their genetics, their previous training status, their expectations, etc. So you have external load, which are, you know, all the parameters of your training, individuals characteristics, you add them together and you get the internal load and you can measure this with things like heart rate change, or things like RPE, a particular set, or a session RPE. And overall, internal workloads can be described as a measure of the perception of effort by the athletes themselves. So what's interesting here is that subjective metrics like RPE, session RPE, etc. correlate better with injury risk than external factors like intensity, volume, etc. For example, the acute chronic workload ratio considers the training load that the athlete has performed relative to the training load that he or she has been prepared for. In practice, this means that the workload assigned to a liftor should not be too much greater than what they are able to currently tolerate. So one way to measure this is to actually compare the current weeks training to the previous four weeks of training and just make sure that the increase isn't too great. That being said, it's hard to be confident about using a specific interval here like should it be this week compared to the previous four weeks, previous three weeks, previous two weeks probably needs to be adjusted for each sport. It's also hard to be confident in how some of the state actually applies to resistance training since it's still pretty new and we're kind of sucing out the details even in how to measure it. So the way that we're currently comparing workloads are by using session RPE and the duration of the session in minutes and we're comparing the average weekly values compared to the previous four weeks average. And just kind of seeing like, hey, what's the ratio between the acute workload to the chronic workload? That's rather complicated and I think one practical tool that you can take home is to start rating your session RPE. session RP, again, it's a scale going from one to ten, 10 being very very hard, one being very, very easy. If you note that most of your training sessions are RP 10, session RP 10, you're laying it all out there that probably portends a bad outcome. Some sessions may be very, very difficult but they all shouldn't be maximal all the time. Conversely, if they're very, very low, say less than five, that probably means that they're a little too easy for your given fitness level. And so therefore, may not be adding to the sort of training stress that's needed to drive for their adaptations. So again, it's important to make sure that the current level of training is reflective of your previous level of training and that you're not going up too quickly too soon because that's probably going to lead to a bad outcome. The next extrinsic factor that's meaningful is managing stress. And this is something we talk about all the time. So this is stress from work, school, interpersonal relationships, et cetera, all part of the individual characteristics that influence the internal load. So again, external load or all the objective values of the training session and then your individual characteristics sort of interpret that or filter it like an Instagram post and gives you the internal load. That's a result. And so we actually have some decent data here on this. So for example, a division one study on their collegiate athletes, they had a much higher risk of injury when academic stress was high than when it was low despite training and competition schedules being the same during both periods. And so one way that you can get around this is by having an auto regulated program where you're allowing for these day-to-day variations fluctuations or even week-to-week variations and fluctuations in your not only readiness to train, but also the resources you have for adapting to and tolerating that training. Speaking of training, becoming well-trained is a great way to reduce your injury risk. And we call this the training injury prevention paradox. This is a phenomena where athletes accustomed to high training loads tend to have fewer injuries that athletes training at a lower workload. This is also known as the workload injury paradox whereby higher chronic workload is protective against injury when acute workload is similar to that chronic workload. So training more and becoming more well-trained tends to reduce the risk of injury. So gradually increasing the training load over time so you can handle more workload tends to be a good idea to reduce the risk of injury. There's some evidence for this with respect to higher level lifters actually having a lower injury risk. We talked about that a few minutes ago. And the takeaway here is that when you actually again look at the higher level lifters, the elite level lifters, they're actually training at much higher volumes, much higher frequencies usually than newer lifters and yet their injury risk tends to either be the same or lower in these studies that we actually have inside it here. So what you would expect is that since they're participating in more and more training that they're actually at risk, higher risk for for injuries but in fact they're not in there. It appeared to be again sort of able to tolerate this increased level of training due to rashing up that workload over time becoming more well-trained. Probably one of the biggest extrinsic factors that we can actually modify here is getting stronger. Unfortunately, there's no data on powerlifting or barbell sports on actually like, oh, however strong you are correlates to your injury risk. But in other sports, there's clear data here. So for example, a study on 26,000 athletes showed that improving strength reduced sports injuries to less than one-third and overuse injuries could be reduced by half. Another study analyzing injury risk reduction from strength training showed a 10% increase in strength training volume reduced the risk of injury by more than 4% at points. Overall, this probably kind of falls or ties into that become well-trained category. As getting stronger over time requires more training and therefore the tolerance or being able to tolerate increased training load. One thing we can't leave out we're talking about barbell sports are accidents. So for instance, dropping weights on feet are fairly common, accidents in the weight room are common with actual increased risk in younger individuals who presented to the emergency department. Injuries were classified as accidental if it was caused by dropping a weight or improper equipment use. So in a sample of over 4,000 patients, a 77% of the injuries seen in the age group 8 to 13 were due to accidental injuries. So again, dropping a weight or improper equipment use were as 27 and a half percent of all weight room related injuries were accidental in the age group 22 to 30. So still significant, watch your toes, don't drop weights on your toes if you can avoid that. In addition to accidents, a catastrophic injuries do happen but they're relatively rare. And so you look at case reports to kind of see like, hey, what sort of things are happening? Is there any way to reduce the risk from these catastrophic injuries? And I don't think so outside of safety practices in the gym. So for example, there's one study that reported a clavicle fracture that occurred during the bench press. Somebody broke their collarbone during the bench press. Another case report where a guy had a simultaneous rotator cuff and biceps tendon tear during strong manic competition. I'm not sure that there's anything that you can do to reduce the risk there. Okay. And fortunately fatal accidents in the weight room are relatively rare. So again, only handful of case reports here. The first report I found was a nine-year-old boy had a 23 kilo barbell fallen his chest from the uprights on a bench support in the home. So I assume that there was a bench press in the home and there was an oddly specific yet non-standardized 23 kilo barbell just resting on the uprights and any event this bar came down landed on their chest. The kids chest and twirl hold on his right atrium did not survive that unfortunately. The second report, weight lifter who was using animal steroids, experienced sudden cardiac death, although the sudden cardiac death might have been due to an arrhythmia, due to a congenital defect in certain ion channels which can happen too. Overall, I'm not sure that we can actually reduce the risk of these types of events. I can't watch Hey guys, this is Dr. Michael Ray, I'm a Barbell Medicine Pain and Reheat clinician I'm coming to you today with a video about our latest blog that we just released regarding exercise and persistent pain Now in this blog I review an article by Plaskiedl titled Exercise and Doose Hyperalegesia, a meta analysis of exercise dosing for the treatment of chronic pain If you're not from the other type of olegesia, it's just a fancy way of saying decreased pain perception Now we know that this is an important issue, persistent pain is estimated to affect about 1.5 billion people worldwide today And to the main stage treatments that are usually recommended are both education to the patient about pain And then also go oriented activity interventions or exercise Exercise the difficult part about this discussion is we actually don't have a lot of solid data and good knowledge on what's an appropriate exercise dosage For patients dealing with persistent pain and in particularly specific pain states That's something that Plaski seeks to share a little bit more light on So Plaski took data from a 2017 Cocken review by Genon and reexamine that data to see if we could have DOSage effects with exercise on persistent pain states Now Genon from the 2017 Cocker interview had this to say about the totality of evidence for exercise and persistent pain states The evidence in this overview suggests that the broad spectrum of physical activity and exercise interventions assessed here A aerobic strength flexibility range of motion core or balance training programs as well as yoga, Pilates and Tai Chi All potentially beneficial though the evidence for benefit is low quality and inconsistent The most commonly reported adverse events for increased soreness or muscle pain which subsided after several weeks of the intervention Physical activity and exercise main proof pain severity as well as physical functioning quality of life So based on what Genon had to say from the 2017 Cocker review it appears There was not exactly an overwhelming amount of evidence will support for the recommendation of exercise or particular dosage for individuals for system pain And this new article by Plaski out of all the authors sought to understand how altering the dose of exercise might affect pain They say the primary objective is to test the hypothesis that the dose of exercise would impact the efficacy of exercise and physical movement based therapy To reduce persistent or chronic pain For this new review, Plaski out of the site to utilize randomized control trials from the 2017 Cocker review That included adult patients, 18 years of older chronic non-cancel pain defined as greater than three months in duration And it is a meta analysis reporting post intervention effect sizes for pain It was put in the final caveat was the included articles had to be published in a peer review journal Now the Cocker review originally included I want to say 21 papers 381 individual studies now Plaski ended up including 75 individual studies that met their inclusion criteria The pain states that they looked at were inclusive of rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia, low back pain, intermittent clodication, neck pain, spinal cord injury, and fatella for more pain syndrome Those were included pain states When they wanted to look at exercises effects on those pain states, they then had to classify the exercises that were utilized in these interventions And they did this kind of broadly, they classify the exercise modalities as either strength or resistance training, aerobic exercise, either land or water And then meditative movement therapy Now they further subdivided from these broad categories and to things like walking, jogging, pilates, tai chi Motor control exercises range of motion, flexibility exercises, aquatic aerobics, resistance training and land aerobic exercise They talk about that a lot more in the article which I definitely recommend reading So once the authors categorize the exercise interventions, they needed to then classify the exercise dosage For each exercise intervention to look at its effect on the pain states particularly So they classify the exercise dosage, based off of frequency intensity, time, and duration Frequency is defined as the number of bouts of exercise performed within a week So for example, if they performed the exercise intervention three times that week, then the frequency would be three Intensity was defined as absolute intensity in which they took metabolic equivalent units, nets And they multiplied that by the number of minutes performed in one week For time that was a cumulative amount of time and minutes the exercise was completed per week So if they completed it 60 minutes and those three times per week, that would be 180 minutes of time per week And finally duration was the weeks the exercises were implemented in the study So if the study went on for 12 weeks, then the duration was at 12 week intervention So again they just classify those in the frequency intensity, time, and duration For each exercise intervention and it looked at how the dosage effects particular pain-based states So overall the author states that they found that most of the studies included in this review Demonstrated some positive benefits of exercise up pain outcomes that was 69 of the 75 included studies Of which 30 were statistically significant So less than half Of the statistically non-significant studies 39 or 45 described positive training benefits of exercise Why only six studies reported worse pain with exercise? Now that last part of that statement is kind of intriguing When we see things like trending towards statistically significant That's more of a view to or a trickery where it's not really telling us anything meaningful But rather perhaps it's trying to force someone's bias of wanting to support exercise interventions for Efficacious ways to help people with persistent pain Trending towards statistically significant isn't very meaningful in this regard So the reason article about Pulaski at L just further demonstrates our lack of knowledge regarding a proper exercise dosage For those dealing with persistent pain We seem to know that it's beneficial but at what frequency intensity time and duration We're really not sure it's not like the national physical activity guidelines that we have in the US But we have some understanding of an appropriate baseline level of dosage to incur health benefits on the participant We're not quite there yet with persistent pain You know it has a lot of positive benefits We're just not sure what their proper dosage is Now this shouldn't be looked at as a net negative The way that we can see this as clinicians Is this means we can work collaboratively with patients Define with their appropriate dosage for them Based off of their goals Their ability to hear long-term and most likely that's going to be related to something that they enjoy And then finally looking at their prior training history all of those could culminate into getting together Some type of what I would prefer to call movement activity or cold erected movement activity That they can utilize to work through the issue to currently dealing with And then maybe if we can get by and long-term for all the other positive physiological adaptations from exercise Then we get something that they want to do long-term throughout life Even with the understanding that maybe their interest change It would be very easy as a member of the Barbel medicine team I personally very much enjoyed resistance training Specifically with the barbell But as someone came to me working through one of these pain-based states that they discussed in this paper And they weren't very into barbel training They knew that it wasn't something they're going to do in the future And they just didn't have any interest Then I'm probably going to find other exercises to incur the effect that I'm looking for That they think they could adapt to their lifelong term We know exercise adaptations on a spectrum Some of the ceases doing the exercise the minute they leave our clinic Then is probably going to not have a long-term benefit for them One final point that I do think is important to state here We do know that it's okay to allow patients dealing with persistent pain-based symptoms to exercise with pain And there may be some short-term benefits and allowing such an approach By decreasing connesia phobia Instilling self-efficacy and teaching the patient that pain doesn't equal tissue damage necessitating avoidance and protection Hert doesn't equal harm in the scenario Either way, hopefully the findings from this review Help stifle claims that one must do a particular exercise dosage Type frequency intensity time and duration to get themselves out of pain And rather reframe focus on defining the patient's preferred exercise dosage Based on activity history and individual goals

=== FILE: How Does Weight Loss Change Cholesterol Levels？ [I3MVuKYKZvQ].txt ===

How are lipid panels affected by dieting? So in general, let's talk about after you've lost weight, right? So you've dieted and lost weight and then we'll talk about what happens while you're actively dieted. After you lost weight, usually a 5 to 10% weight loss produces a about 10 to 15% reduction in LDL and maybe a little bit greater reduction in triglycerides, which can be useful. Particularly if you were carrying too much body fat before. If you lose more weight, you can see a greater decrease in those numbers, right? So if you lost 20% body weight, you may see a given greater decrease in your LDL and your triglycerides. And in general, HDL tends to stay the same. If you start exercise at the same time, HDL may even increase overall good. Now the nuance here is that if you were a candidate for statins prior to losing weight, meaning that your 10-year risk of having a bad outcome. So you were a 10-year risk of having a heart attack or stroke or something like that was high and you were a good candidate for statins. The treatment goal for LDL reduction is 50%. 50. Reduce your LDL by 50%. And so if the average amount of LDL reduction you can expect by reducing your body weight 5 to 10%, which is a pretty substantial weight loss, right? Is 10 to 15%. You're not getting there. You're less than 3 times less than the sort of that minimum threshold. So it doesn't mean that you shouldn't even try to lose weight, just take the statins, forpig pharma. Now what I'm saying is just that we should not avoid medications when they provide clear benefit. And it doesn't mean that the person maybe necessarily needs to be on a statin forever. It's just to reduce that risk, substantially going forward. Maybe that's the initial movement. What happens to the lipid panel while you're actually dieting. You can think about this as the body fat. You're actually liberating a lot of stored fat into the bloodstream and you're using it for fuel. And so a blood test, particularly a cholesterol test, is a snapshot in time of how much fat is in your blood, how much fat is being carried around by certain proteins in your blood. And so let's say then you stick the needle in the vein, pull out the blood. Oh crap, there's way more fat in your blood at this particular time. It's like, well yeah, it's on its way to the muscle tissue to be oxidized for fuel, for example. And so you see that all the time that people, their triglyceride levels will be significantly elevated while they're losing weight. Sometimes even their LDL will be elevated while they're losing weight. It usually doesn't happen after you've lost weight and you're weight has plateaued, but certainly during weight loss. So the recommendation for lipid panel intervals is about, is every six months, I believe, after you've initiated it, all of those some clinicians will do three month intervals. I, when I was actively seeing patients and somebody was trying to lose weight and for lifestyle, we were trying to lifestyle recommendations initially. I would effectively try to schedule that second lipid test till after a period of time, we were given that a lose weight and then maintain it. Meaning that if it's going to take you more than three months to kind of lose the weight, I would extend the interval time so that you are weight neutral, maintaining your weight, your new lower weight before I tested. Got another lipid test. Yeah, I don't think there's a great reason to check lipid panel super frequently. I mean, I, I, I, I, I, I definitely, every three months is, is I think too frequent to be super useful. I would just not check blood tests while you are actively aggressively trying to lose weight and then check things, you know, like that after things have stabilized. So, good.

=== FILE: How To Get Motivated To Exercise？ [8J0qsTNU1lc].txt ===

All right, number 10. Any tips or techniques you find generally helpful for increasing motivation or discipline and training? I mean, this is a tough one. It is a tough one, but I think I go back to some of the stuff we talked about during the behavioral change lecture, and then additionally we kept sprinkling in. I think you should enjoy this. I think you should enjoy not only the training you're doing, but the components of that, but the actual process, so your goal-oriented training. So I think if somebody is like really having a hard time sticking to it, I'd wonder like, do you like what you're doing? Is this enjoyable for you? And if it is, great. So what's holding you back? Because there are some things that come up that people generally respond to in a way where they might need some additional counseling. So for instance, if somebody misses day one of the workout, I've seen it a lot of times where people will just not work out the rest of the week. They're like, I missed my first day, this week's off. I'm just going to repeat this week next week. They think it's like all they're not in for nominal. And it's like, nope, don't do that. Or like, no, but if I don't work out today, then tomorrow's my scheduled rest day, then I'll have to work out tomorrow. And then have to work out the back to back and that's like bad because I need to perform optimally on all these days. And it's like, no, just put all the workouts together. We have like a literally a litany of different questions on our form that's like, hey, I'm leaving town for the week on Thursday, on Friday. And I have four workouts to do this week, what new? And it's like workout Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, going your vacation. And I don't say that like to be dismissive, right? But it's like the actual acute performance during your workout doesn't really matter as much as you get into the total training. So that's just one common thing that I see all the time and people are struggling for time resources in order to train. And I think working around that can help people stay adherent to the training program provided they like what they're doing. But if someone hates what they're doing, right, or is fearful of what they're doing, that's problematic. The third thing that I find really important is the social aspect here. So if people are doing this by themselves, so like they have a home gym and they're the only one in their house that uses the home gym, or if none of their family members work out, even immediate or extended, none of their friends work out, they're just effectively leaving their social circle. They're saying, I'm going to leave my family, I got to leave all my friends and I go to the gym where I don't know that many people, that's a hard sell for a lot of people. And so I think that to the degree, you can leverage social support, you can make things more effective, a second economical from a time perspective, and then make it enjoyable. Those are my big sort of things that you can practically apply to the programming and the social support network to get people to adhere to training. But as far as actually finding motivation in people, that's stuff. You got to give them the old gipper talk. Why, what do you want to do with this? What do you want to get out of this? Where do you want to be in three months, six months, 12 months? How do your actions on a daily basis lead you closer to or further away from that particular goal? Something. Yeah, yeah, I think I don't love the, I don't love centering this discussion around the idea of discipline at all. We've talked in some of our previous Q&As and on podcasts and stuff like that that, you know, in the past decade, we can count how many workouts we've missed on one hand or less. Even last week, when I was laid up with the flu, I still went out and did my deadlift day on Tuesday. And like I said, I almost passed out trying to pull 405 and people might say, you're an idiot, you're crazy for trying to go do that. And I was like, well, I think back to that day, right? I'm having like coughing and chills and sweat on the couch and I feel like shit. Why did I go out to the gym and try to do that? Was it because I'm just like a total badass and more disciplined than anyone else on earth? No, it's because I actually enjoyed training. And I got up that day and I was like, well, today would normally be a training day and I liked training. So it would make me feel better. Maybe if I went out and tried to do something. Now, I probably tried to pull more than I was ready for on that day, right? But I did it because I actually enjoy training. If I loathed training, if I hated training and I felt that sick, that's like double barrier to try to go out and do that thing, right? So I look back to why have we not missed a training session in the past decade, basically, or a couple, right? Because we actually enjoy training. And to the extent that maybe we've we both definitely like skipped out on certain like, say, social engagements or something, because we, because training was more important to us, it's because we enjoy doing that, right? So the enjoyment piece, I think, is under-emphasized underrated. It's not that, you know, we're just like better than you because we can do this thing that we hate, right? Even when we don't want to, hey, we actually enjoy doing this thing. So I think finding that like why you're doing this and trying to play that up is a bigger piece there than just saying, you're not disciplined enough to do this, right? You're a bad person because you didn't do this session because you're not disciplined enough. I don't think that that's a good way to view human behavior really in general. Also Rick Ross helps. So since none of these are going to bring you enough business to like warrant. Getting one over another, I just don't care. I told you my GPA earlier, so you guys should be well aware of like my ability to like learn things. So not high.
