=== FILE: How to Re-Start Training After a Layoff [c4NNE6eox4c].txt ===

Jordan said, boy, anytime I see that in a question, I just like, I probably didn't say that. Yeah, probably. Here we are. Jordan said during the seminar that enjoyment and exercise has the biggest impact on endurance. Oh, that's true. I did say that coming back to lifting after a long layoff, I found it difficult to find enjoyment with weights that are so far below when I used to be able to do any suggestions or resources on how to start enjoying training again. I don't have any resources on this. It'd be great if we had a book. It was like enjoying training. Like, it just like a whole book. I'm like how to make starting enjoyment. Yeah, starting starting starting, starting pleasure. You know, just, yes. I'm lifting weights very pleasurable. Yeah, that's gross. So this is a good start. Starting hedonism. Yeah, a way to use my weights to, yeah. I actually do have a strategy for this because this happened to me. I did cross it for like eight months. Yeah, I experimented with the dark, dark arts. And I lost a substantial amount of weight in a substantial amount of strength. I'm not sure those two things were related because I wasn't really lifting weights. During that time, I was doing a bunch of Olympic lifts. And it just, I wasn't squatting, eventually. You're deadlifting. Yeah, I'm a weight went down as well. So when I came back, I remember I squatted. I used Leah's belt. This is how like, yeah, kick kick. Yes, yes. This is how, this is how like, kick kick I was. That was a hundred. I remember I came back from Australia. And I was 84 kilos, 85 kilos, which is like all of 185 pounds or something like that. And I usually as belt and I squat at 180 kilos, which is 396 for a hard triple, a hard triple. To be clear, I've benched that before for a triple. So like things were bad. And I was like, what? So I'd recently decided to like quit doing CrossFit because I didn't like it. And then, yeah, so enjoyment was low. And I was like, I was going back to powerlifting because I love that. And then I did powerlifting for one day. And I was like, no, where's all my strength? So the strategy that I used on the exercises that I had a lot of history with. So squat bench deadlift, I changed the rep range to things I didn't have experience with. So for example, I'd never really done squats or deadlift for sets of eight and ten. I stuck to mostly those. And I picked different exercise variations that I had very little experience with. And previously, so that I didn't have this like historical like performance, a barometer that I kept going up against. So I did that. And honestly, I remember it was like six to eight weeks after I came back. I was within about 10% of my normal strength levels. And so I was happy again and could train like relatively regularly. Benefits of this are kind of twofold. One, you don't hate yourself every time you go to the gym and think, what was me? This is the worst I've ever performed in my whole life. And then benefit number two is that you're sort of slow, gradually retraining yourself to do a different thing. So remember, I had been doing CrossFit for eight months. I was not squatting, benching and deadlifting like I was during my normal powerlifting training. Had I just switched back to powerlifting with no sort of bridge in between that could have potentially been problematic for me. However, I had this sort of on-ramp where I was able to sort of get back to the normal training. And so that worked out pretty well for me. So generally that's how I recommend folks do that. If they have a specific goal that's different than their normal that we've been training for for a while. And then they want to go back to a previous type of training. I put program this like GPP-related bridge where the rep ranges are different. The exercise selection is different so they don't have this like, again, historical thing that they're comparing themselves against each single time. You can do that a lot of different ways. You can do that with rep ranges. You can do it with adding chains or bands or different barbells or different sort of range of motion or tempo. There's a whole different things, a lot of different things you can use. I just actually dealt with this very scenario although not entirely due to a lift off. I had a patient of mine who I have been working with for a little while who was recently diagnosed with cancer. And specifically he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and one of the standard treatments for prostate cancer is what's called endrogen deprivation therapy where you basically get put on testosterone blockers. You can think of it like that. You get like chemically castrated basically to prevent endrogen stimulating the prostate cancer from growing anymore. So we're intentionally making him hypogonaddle and he was observing that his performance was going down in the gym. When you're truly hypogonaddle, then sure we would expect that your performance is going to be altered with that. And he was having some distress over this because he pulled 500 at national last year and now he's like I'm seeing my numbers start to change. And so what should I do? I'm not really loving training when I'm weaker. And I just said we need to change the metrics of performance here. We need to pick some different exercises, right? Rather than a competition squat and a competition deadlift than a positive bench press, we need to pick some other things that you haven't done before. Give you some new opportunities to PR, right? So now that if you're going to be doing pulse squats and deficit deadlifts and stuff like that, every time you train is going to be a PR. And so we change the strategy and he's now fully on board with that idea and training with some different things. So again, same deal so that he doesn't have this constant prior performance to compare himself to. So that's what we did with him. So effectively the same thing, just do different things and you'll have less of a metric of comparison. Yeah, just change the goalpost. Boom.

=== FILE: How-To Address Pain Without Being A Nocebo [9LXK_V9GcLg].txt ===

What would you recommend for managing slash receiving feedback on pain in the clinical world so that's not to ignore patient's perceptions but still maximize the rehab process? I can start. Alright. So this was the reference where I was talking about how if you're a coach and your coach and somebody who has some discomfort, say in their back, after every rep or after every set, you're asking, how's your back feeling? How's your back feeling? How's your back feeling? Constantly drawing more attention to that area because we know that a tensional focus plays a big role in people's experience of pain. And so I would make the recommendation to not do that when you're coaching people. This isn't to swing the other way into say just to ignore any symptom that they report but you don't necessarily need to go fishing for that. In a rehab context, if you were a skilled clinician and observer and communicator with your patient, then you can observe what they're doing and then just ask them what their thoughts are. After a given set, how'd that go? Do you feel comfortable increasing the load? Something like that. And given that you've had the discussion, the education process ahead of time, saying, we're going to work in a range of tolerable symptoms and aim to progress gradually from there, then you can get that feedback. They can volunteer it to you rather than you go and fishing for it from them. So to the point where if they're feeling comfortable and okay, then you can celebrate that and say, that's awesome, that's great news. You're feeling good, that's a good sign. We can keep progressing in this process. Whereas if they volunteer that this is pretty uncomfortable or I'm concerned about this or this is freaking me out or I don't want to go up anymore, then you can respect that and maybe have a discussion around it and modify the plan accordingly rather than constantly going again, fishing and drawing their attention to an area that their attention may not necessarily be on. Focusing their attention more on the task and celebrating the victory of that went well. I think is probably the way that I would go in a clinical context. I recognize, however, that in the clinical world there's some tendency and rule, potentially even rules and requirements to get patients pain scores on a scale of 1 to 10 and that can be annoying. I don't need to do a pain score on a scale of 1 to 10 after every set either. So I would do the bare minimum on that front as far as getting your pain scores and then just focusing on the task and not unnecessarily drawing attention to where it doesn't need to be. I think the only, just to have practical sense, I actually don't recommend that most coaches ask about it. If you notice somebody who's demonstrating pain-related behavior which during a lift would be slow down, that occurs during the descent of a squat, for example, or hesitation during a particular lift that is abnormal because you've worked with this person before. You can ask, hey, was that painful for you? Or you can ask them even a more open-ended question, like what's going on? Just to get them to start talking about it. But my general recommendation is to not ask, does that hurt after any set? The only time I think that's appropriate is if you're trying new stuff, to try to work around an existing injury and you're on the fly, trying new things to see if they're still sensitive to that particular movement. Someone had low back pain like Leah when we were trying to gather in Santa Cruz quite frequently. If she had a low back pain, we do a mid-shin rack pull and after she did a set of how that feel, how that feel is the right question there. And then if that didn't, she said, I still, still pretty sensitive, it's still a pretty good. We try another thing and I would say, again, how does that feel? Something like that. I think the big thing that people, I don't know if they feel this way, but I certainly think it gets perceived this way, it's like you have to be perfect with this pain stuff. And if you mess up, dang it, I ruined it. That's not the case. We all make mistakes. We all say the wrong things sometimes. Important part is, the important part is to not compound an error with another error. Like, oh, did that hurt? Oh, no, I said it. I said the H word. I'm saying, now you're freaking out about it and they're like, what? And so some of that actually gets transferred to them and they're like, they start feeling guilty about having pain. The normal human experience. And then the stuff can start snowballing. And so I think it's just like, yeah, look, we all make mistakes and don't use the right language all the time. We have certain goals for how we communicate and let's try to do the best we can. But in the coaching setting, I think it just plan on saying how does that feel. If you notice something strange. Yeah.

=== FILE: How-To Assess Self Efficacy [vRP021pAg24].txt ===

Music Question number two, how do you assess self-efficacy during your initial evaluation? Oh, this is a great question. Well, you just ask them what's your self-efficacy in it? No, this is usually like, huh? So, barring any proprietary methods like that pamphleter team, which I've never used personally. I just, you know, found it on the internet to torrent it, just to see what it was. Really interesting. But some of the questions are, can be useful or the styles of questions. So, admittedly, in barbell medicine, and so, that's what I do now. It's my full time job. This is not something I need to usually directly assess. Being like, to try to figure out, does this person have resources, skills, like, you know, to go out there, you know, you like, you like, to go out there, and, you know, try to take ownership of their own health and the role that they play in their own health. But, in residency, you know, a question I would often ask people is, you know, what do you view your role in all of this to be? So, if we're talking about a disease status or like a new diagnosis or there are long-term chronic disease, like, so what is your role in this, in this sort of process? It is a question, like, a loaded question because a person might be like, either I've never thought about it or it immediately, like, I don't feel great about that. But that's not necessarily a bad thing because if they feel sort of bad about it or responsible, that's what I want them to feel responsible for. I don't want to feel bad. I want them to feel like I do take responsibility for my own health and I feel like I'm in control. That's those are signs of self-efficacy. If someone were to say, I don't feel like I play any role in this, I don't have any responsibility. That's the opposite. That's low self-efficacy. And so assessing what resources skills, tools, somebody else has available to them is a whole, another line of questions. And so going in with more open-ended questions specific to the sort of behavioral change you're targeting. So if it's exercise, be like, okay, what sort of exercise would you like to do, what sort of strategies do you have to become more physically active, what sort of access do you have? And sort of then you're starting to assess like how far people have gone on their own. And that, again, gives you a clue how much self-efficacy to the half. If someone was super motivated, ready to change their behavior, and had a high level self-efficacy, I probably wouldn't be seeing them for to change their physical activity patterns because they'd already done it. Right? So I'm trying to find the hang-up. Right? Where do I need to come in and either provide if it's knowledge, okay? If it's additional strategies, okay? If it's additional resources, okay? It just, you're trying to kind of work down that rabbit hole to figure out where you come in, rather than starting from the beginning and not going through any of that and saying, here's the plan. Yeah, assessing self-efficacy. I think emerges naturally just from having a conversation with somebody. I presented during the pain lecture a bunch of examples of the kind of open-ended questions that will ask people during this evaluation for almost anything, whether it's medical, pain related, et cetera. You know, what do you think is going on, what are your biggest concerns, have you dealt with this before, what did you do then, what do you know, what do you think is going on, et cetera. And through all that, just listening to their answers, you can get a feel for where somebody said is that was something. There are certain validated questionnaires for self-efficacy and certain context. There's, for example, a pain self-efficacy questionnaire, PSEQ. But once you start down that rabbit hole, it is easy to get way too excited about questionnaires. You can use questionnaires and scales to evaluate everything. There's a Tampa scale for Canisia, FObia, there's a catastrophizing scale, there's a pain self-efficacy questionnaire, there's questionnaires for literally everything you can think of backpack and, you know, all the, there's way too many of them. And eventually your whole encounter with somebody is them filling out questions. So I think that's something that probably more useful in my opinion for research purposes to actually measure things like differences in self-efficacy over the course of a particular intervention. If that's what the study wanted to look at in real world practice, I don't think you need a questionnaire to do that. I think you need to, you know, be a human and interact with another human and have a conversation and get a sense of where they're at, where they're coming from. The downside is that takes time, right? And so you need to be in a clinical environment where you actually have the time to do that. So that can be tricky. Where's the AI self-efficacy? Yeah.

=== FILE: How-To Explain Pain to Others [FEsQ70Ci76k].txt ===

What are the most quick and effective analogies you've used to explain pain to patients? The first caveat that I would say here is I typically don't go into these encounters with the aim of explaining pain to a patient. The patient knows what pain is, what it feels like. They're coming to me telling me this hurts. I don't have to tell them what it means to hurt or what hurt is. Rather, I'm there to help them make sense of their experience to understand what it means, what it doesn't mean and what they can do about it if anything. Usually, there are a lot of things that can be done about it. So I think that we need to be cautious about, because, you know, and most of us when we learn a lot of this kind of new-fangled pain stuff that's actually been around for a few decades at this point, you get excited to just kind of like, you know, burst into the exam room and start, you know, telling your patient how it is. It's like the cool kid guy. Oh yeah. Here's what you're feeling in your back and they're like, what? Yeah. Right. So I think first and foremost, in all of these encounters where I'm having these kind of conversations with patients, I'm generally asking them to tell me about what they're experiencing and then I just shut up and let them tell me. And I even do the same thing outside of Musco-Scale pain related issues when I'm in the hospital and the ER, somebody might be coming in with something else that I actually need to admit them to the hospital for and I'm not there to necessarily kick in the door and tell them what's going on. I said, tell me what's going on and I just zip it and let them talk. At some point, I need to start getting more involved in the conversation, but anytime I find myself talking more than the patient is, that's a red flag to me that something's not right. And I tell my residents and students that, particularly when they get to talk into too much, you should be probably talking a little bit less. I want to hear more from them. With that said, once it gets to the point where I've assessed the patients understanding of what this pain means, then that may be a place where I can kind of confront some of those beliefs and aim to redirect those a little bit. So if their belief is, yeah, I have this pain in my back when I've been over and I think it, you know, every time I have that pain, it means that my joints are grinding away against one another and that's why I'm having pain. Well, that's something that I probably need to correct. I need to nudge that in a different direction. Otherwise, when I ask them to go and bend over and exercise, to pick up a load off the floor or something like that, then that's a situation where that interpretation where they're like, oh, no, my joints are grinding together. I can't do this. This is unsafe. I can't time I should use camp at my sock on. So I have to alter that meaning, that understanding that they have. So a simple kind of metaphor that you'll hear used a lot in this world is just kind of the idea of pain as an alarm system. That's one where it's very easy to discuss it. Patients can understand that fairly readily. You can also build in the concepts of kind of sensitivity to that, into that discussion and kind of help to alter their understanding of what pain means to guide them on the right path. But I just caution people not to jump to that sort of aggressive over-explaining to soon to early before you've listened to the person and gotten a sense of where they're coming from. Yeah. I think people are trying to have deeper discussions with patients or even other people about pain. The analogy that I like that I think makes the most sense to me as far as the complexity of what's actually going on is that pain is an experience similar to hunger. Like hunger is an experience and that there are many different inputs into why you become hungry and why you have pain. So for example, you don't always just hungry when your body is low on energy or needs calories. So it's not just biological, but there are social inputs. If you see people around you eating, you smell that tasty donut, you see food for example, you might become hungry. There are psychological things that go on that affect your dietary intake or you want to eat or not and that's similar to pain that they're all these sort of different inputs that get integrated into that experience. And so when people start to understand the complexity, then you can further explain this. If people need it, but you don't need to have this in-depth discussion with somebody about pain until you've figured out what their story is and why they're there, why they're not ready to eat it. Well, yeah, exactly. It's not everybody's ready to eat it. So if your friend says, yeah, man, I threw my back out this morning, I'm not going to make it to the gym or whatever. Yeah, so let me tell you about pain. Pain's like hunger, you see. And sometimes you just got to let the big dog eat. It's like, wait, what? It's like, I don't know, I went to a seminar. That's what I took home. It's not what we said. Okay. Yeah. So in general, I kind of wait for somebody to ask me to weigh in on these things before I actually weigh in on them.

=== FILE: How-To Manage Training And Shiftwork [QRoYH35UHWM].txt ===

How can you best mitigate the effect of shift work like 24-hour shifts such as naps to catch up on sleep? And then how do you not know CBO yourself into thinking you'll have a bad day? Because you didn't get enough sleep or some other factor that is far from ideal. I can start. So this is something that I think both of us have some experience with. Having been through periods of time already did 24-28 hour shifts somewhat regularly. And there's not a great way to get quality sleep during that period of time, particularly when those shifts can be unpredictable. So there may have been some of those shifts where I was able to get some sleep during the shift. There are some where I had to be awake, alert and doing things the entire time. And obviously there ends up being a consequence afterwards. Some of those days after the shift will crash harder than others, or if you end up getting some sleep on the shift, maybe you don't sleep as much. And so the unpredictability, the variability, is problematic. It results in you generally not feeling awesome. And I think that is unfortunately probably part of the deal with doing 24-hour shifts with any degree of regularity. You're not going to feel completely awesome or completely normal all the time. If they're more spaced out and relatively infrequent, then you can try to get on as consistent of a sleep schedule as you can in between. And that'll restore some semblance of normal sleep. But just the idea was sleep in general and that this should be the takeaway if you listen to our podcast on sleep that we did with our friend Dr. Gordon. Is that consistency is kind of what tends to be the name of the game here. In particular, if we can get our patients who we have with insomnia, if we can get them waking up at the same time every single day, then that ends up resulting in developing sufficient sleep drive. Over time, such that they end up kind of falling into a more normal sleep cycle rhythm. But obviously this is a big barrier to having a consistent sleep schedule. You just have to do the best you can in terms of consistency. As far as the other part of the question, where it had to do with not kind of crushing yourself by thinking you're going to have a bad session just because you didn't get enough sleep or some other factor. I think this comes into the discussion I had earlier comparing external versus internal load. So external load being the absolute weight on the bar, whereas internal load describes the response to that training stimulus that we measure using RPE. I think that if people who have excessive focus on the importance or the significance of the external load, they put all their value and self-worth on the absolute weight on the bar, I think you're going to have some trouble with this situation. Right? Because you're going to put so much value on lifting a particular weight on a particular day at a particular time and your life, the cards are just not going to fall that way. You get to that day, that time, go to lift that weight and maybe it doesn't go. Right? And that's tough. That's why we like having more as Jordan said, maliability, flexibility in your training program, where you view the training process differently. You don't view the training process as something where you have to lift a specific weight. Rather, you're saying, I'm the weight on the bar, the rep I'm doing is merely a strategy to elicit this response that I'm trying to get. Right? And in that sense, you can change the weight on the bar and not freak out about it. Rather, you can pack yourself on the back for saying, I got the desired stimulus for where I am today at this particular time, based on how I'm performing at this moment, given everything else in my life that I may or may not have control over. Right? So it can almost become a win when you go into that session. You use your auto-regulation strategy like RPE. You adjust the load accordingly. You complete the whole session. That's awesome. That's a win. You're doing more than just about anybody else out there who is doing 24 hour shifts. Guaranteed. Right? Instead of viewing it as I was supposed to squat 500 today. Right? But I could only squat 455. I suck. Right? Big difference in how you view that in terms of the training process. So this has a lot to do with kind of how if we're going to be goal-oriented, the nature of goals that we use. Are the goals we use performance-based? Right? Were you insist on performing lifting a particular weight? Are they out-come-based? Like, I'm lifting to win only if you ain't first your last. Right? Or are they process-based goals? Right? I'm going to train all four sessions that I'm supposed to do. I'm going to get my conditioning in, et cetera. And that's my win for the week because my life is crazy like this. So that's the way I view this. It's just reframing how I view the training process in general. I think the only thing I have to add is like if you were trying to set yourself up for success, you would want to control the or maximize the variables that are under your control as much as possible. So for example, you're on 24 hour shift. That doesn't mean, yeah, I'm going to skip three different meals and just have breakfast. For example, before leaving the hospital and three red bowls. Yeah, exactly right. So if you have your nutrition relatively under control with the health promoting dietary pattern, you know, your training is set up to allow some flexibility, rather than having very rigid processes. And then again, ultimately, a scribe in less sort of importance to any single session, any single exercise or any single sort of even input into your training. I mean, I would just assume that you're going to PR anyway, for example. Yeah, like if it's me, if I mean I don't work outside of barbell medicine anymore, this is my main baby, but I wish I could get us on to a night shift because if I go on night shift, I'm going to PR historically, whenever I'm on night shift PR start raining out of nowhere. And I have no idea why I have no reason to stay up at night now. I'm not into generate. So I can't do it. But yeah, I would just assume, all of the things we need to do are going to do great. So having that positive kind of outlook on stuff, good nutrition. And then I don't know that I would recommend NAPS because I just feel like that's not really going to help. It could help acute performance, but if it to the extent of compromise is sleep drive later on, it's probably net negative. So probably wouldn't do that. We just go in and train and go on with my life because that's a good summary of, you know, this whole deal. That's right. Train and go on with your life. Yeah, exactly. Very cool. === FILE: How-To Warm-Up For Deadlifts [BbRJTET9ZsA].txt ===

Alright, so this is the Barbell Medicine Deadlift Forma from a Deadlift workout that Dr. Austin Baraki and I did not too long ago. So Austin's getting ready for deficit deadlifts. I'm getting ready for tempo deadlifts, but we're both going to start with empty barbell deadlifts. This is kind of like a Romanian deadlift, which typically starts at the top and you trace the bar down your legs to a little bit below the kneecap. Usually a few inches. I'd like to think of these as extended range of motion RDLs. You're going to go a little bit further to where the barbell would start if it had plates on it. Now, it typically recommend 2 to 6 sets of 5-8 reps. The idea is you're trying to actually make the muscle warmer and increase the temperature and also get mentally prepared for the task at hand, which in this case is deadlifting. So some external cues that I like is to feel the steel of the barbell, drag the bar up and down the legs, keep it in context. You should feel the steel. And some internal cues that I like are to initiate the movement downwards by pushing the hips back and then also do stand tall at the top. We're not paying much attention here to what the back is doing. Am I in flexion? Am I in extension? Is this quote unquote neutral spine? The reality of it is no matter how you set up, no matter how you deadlift, the spine is going to actively flex when the bar leaves the floor. Now, if you have a lot of flexion or a lot of other spinal movement or some other technique that you'd like to correct to improve efficiency, you can work on those during the empty barbell sets. And then also, obviously, as you're warming up, your work sets should be just C bar, lift bar, because at that point your technique should be relatively dialed for that day. So we did a few sets, about three sets with the empty barbell and go straight to 135. And you can see myself doing tempo work. So I deadlift the weight and set it down under control, because I'm trying to extend the eccentric portion of the lift for this tempo deadlift. Austin is going to switch to deficit poles. So he's using two mats here to space himself up on the ground and crease their engine motion. And you can see he is an active spinal flexion. And we'll discuss that a little bit later, but this isn't really a problem. If you don't make it to the end of the video, he's just actively trying to adapt to that to make a spine more resilient. Now Austin's best pole is 720 pounds, my best pole is 738 pounds. So we typically take plate jumps all the way up to either the midfives or even up to 600 or higher just depends on the day. So we went right to 225. I'm doing doubles. Austin's actually going to work up to a heavy single, but at this point he's still doing reps to try to get warm. So that was 225. This is 315. And again, I'm personally and working on controlling the eccentric. That's the lift for the day. And I'm using those same external cues dragging them all up and down my legs, keeping in contact, feeling the steel. And then initiating the movement downwards, if I push my hips back. Now since Austin is doing a normal tempo, so not extending the eccentric, you can see his lifting velocity is much faster on the eccentric. And I'm still trying to actually move the weight concentrically as quickly as possible. So that's one thing. We really try to coach folks is during the concentric. So on the upwards phase of the deadlift, the upwards phase of the squat, upwards phase of the bench press, or press, trying to move the weight as quickly as possible, obviously while retaining control of the barbell. So again, we jumped from 135 to 225 to 315 to 405 now for 95. Still not using the belt. Austin's actually going to stay beltless during this whole session. Me, I typically don't put my belt on until I get into the mid-fives or over 600 again. It just depends on the jumps I'm taking that day. This is 565. Nice little pull. There, this is 585. And again, extending the eccentric, trying to set the bar down very slowly. And typically, my second rep ends up being slower on the way down because I kind of get into the groove, but we're only doing doubles here. So we'll try to clean up that first rep. Now this is 600 pounds. This is Austin's top single, I believe, from the day. Again, beltless, off a deficit. And yeah, he was in some spinal flexion, but you can tolerate it just fine. And this is my top set, 660, first set of two. Again, trying to move away as quickly as possible during the concentric, even though I know I have to slow it down on the way down. So not as easy to do when you know you have to go slow. So the first rep was probably a little too fast for my preferences on a tempo deadlift, but now I get to go real slow. And that's pretty much our deadlift workout and warm up. Six, six, seven, seven, seven. What's going on? So we basically just did our little deadlift warm up. What we did to deadlift workout. Whole things, basically the same. What are you thinking about when you're warming up on a deadlift? Uh, not really a whole lot to the honest. Right. I mean, I think we've both been deadlifting long enough that it doesn't take a lot of active thought. I think that one thing I do pay attention to, basically from the empty bar on up, is basically like outfields in my hands. Basically at a point where I can kind of get a feel for am I strong today or not as strong today based on how heavy a certain weight feels. Yeah, sure like the velocity of which a reference weight kind of moves probably. But even like when I pick up the empty bar to warm up, if I'm having like a day where I'm like super beat down and very tired, can kind of tell the bar feel a little bit heavier. === FILE: Hypertrophy for Strength Athletes [INHi9m-zWMY].txt ===

All right, related does a strength athlete ever achieve enough hypertrophy? Is there a point in the athletes development whether there is no longer a need to make the muscle larger and only to make them stronger? It's a complicated question. So enough hypertrophy. I mean, that's like saying, you know, you ever get jacked enough. You ever make too much money? I mean, I don't know that you can say yes to that. So as far as in an athletes development where they no longer need to make the muscles larger and only need to make them stronger, that assumes that these happen independently. And I don't know that I view them as like two independent processes. I think that the amount of muscle mass increase that occurs, that co-ocurs with strength increase particularly at high level strength athletes is much smaller than when a occurs in like physique athletes, bodybuilders, et cetera, who are primarily just training for size increases and not at all for strength increases. But I think that there's still some hypertrophy occurring nonetheless even if it's relatively small. Now that being said, the actual hypertrophy process is rather complicated as far as like does the myophibrular hypertrophy just the contractile protein? Is that precede some of the sarcoplasma hypertrophy which tends to create a more substantial increase in muscle cross-sectional area or does the one, you know, precede the other. That stuff's still being assessed out. And so this is still an active area of research. But for from a practical standpoint, I think trying to get as jacked as possible using what while still doing the specific exercises, the specific for your sport and the correct intensity ranges to make them go up would be the goal. I don't ever think you say, I'm jacked enough. I'm going to cut the volume down. Yeah, this part last part of this question or it says there's no longer a need to make the muscles larger and only to make them stronger. I think that creates an kind of an artificial dichotomy or separation between those two things. When really, at least there's there is to be fair some debate in the research world about how much hypertrophy contributes to strength development and performance. But I tend to lean on the side and I think you probably do too that strength performance of a particular muscle, one of the contributing factors to that strength potential is muscle size. The other major contributor would be the neurological like the skill, the recruitment kind of aspect of it. And so you can't really say I don't need to make the muscle larger and only to make it stronger when muscle size is probably a contributor to muscle strength. And so I think that to the extent that you want to continue making your muscle stronger, you should strive to make them larger as well. And I don't think there's actually a way for you to aim to make them stronger without generating some amount of hypertrophy along the way in the process.

=== FILE: Is Bulking and Cutting a Good Strategy？ [B13p0KbQzC0].txt ===

Music Welcome back to the Barbell Medicine YouTube channel. I'm Dr. Jordan Fagginbaum. We have Dr. Awesome Rocky in the studio live in the flesh. That's real. He's in town this week and we decided to answer some questions from the internet. This is for the old Misk forums from Bodybuilding.com. So when you go look at actual scientific evidence on this in-body builders or people who identify as bodybuilders because not like they've all competed. Which is also weird like in the literature. They they they they they set out of flyer like are you a body builder you want to sign up for this study and it's like how do you make sure like show me your NPC that people will gain more lean body mass when they gain more weight. So the more weight you gain and to give in time frame they tend to gain more lean body mass. They also gain more fat mass during that time too. So and there's a huge inter-initual variation with how much lean body mass that people are going to gain and how much fat mass that people are going to gain too. So you know you could have even twins like groups of twins fed the same amount of calorie surplus and one group of twins that are identical are going to gain way more lean body mass compared to the other group of twins. If you want to get bigger and gain more muscle mass I don't see a way around like you're going to have to go into a calorie surplus at some point and then likely you're going to have to go two periods of time where you're reducing fat mass as far as what's the best like stair step model versus like a you know bulk then cut and then maintenance. I don't know that I have hard feelings on that. I do tend to prefer having weight stabilization periods at every step of the game. So when people gain weight they gain a significant amount of muscle mass. I want them to like maintain that weight and then when people lose weight, lose body fat. I want them to maintain that little weight. This weight stabilization period for a couple of weeks before they you know do anything with their calories. You might set yourself up for failure if you do not have these weight stabilization phase. Particularly after weight loss people are like I just lost weight. I'm prime. I'm super animal. I'm going to gain all the lean body mass quickly and it's like actually the biggest signal that your body has physiologically is to restore fat mass. Like so yeah you're the most animal I can ever be but for fat mass not for muscle. Not the cool kind. Not the cool kind. Yeah. So that's the approach I tend to do with the understanding that gaining a lot of lean body mass is going to take a long time. It should be a slow process. That's why like when people like how much of a surplus do I need to be and I'm like it's got small 250 calories, maybe 500 calories and then it's going to take up long time for you to do this anyway and gaining weight rapidly is a good way to gain a lot of fat mass rapidly unless you have great genetics. Right. So and gaining fat mass rapidly is probably not the move, particularly from a health standpoint. So yeah I don't know what the best method is for long term hyper-feet if it's like again just cycling but bulking and cutting but I do like the weight stabilization phases and I like making sure that people are the good candidates for either goal. So if you're already carrying too much fat mass is the bulk. Right. Yeah if your BMI is 30 year above, do not pass go, do not collect $100. Don't bulk. If your weights are conference is approaching that sort of cut point where you have an increased rate of obesity related diseases which there's a specific to your ethnicity. It's about 37 inches for guys for example. Do not don't bulk and in fact you probably should lose weight then probably better. Anything else you want to add to that? Yeah I agree with the fact that with the idea that you're probably not going to be able to get around it I think that there's similarly there to the extent that there may even be a best way to go about it. Right. It is probably going to vary between people like the super freaky genetic people. There may be a better strategy for them and then for people at the other end you know might be in the other direction. The problem is that like you said this is a very very long process and so we don't have any trials comparing bulking cutting group to like people who just steadily maintain like a hundred to 200 calorie surplus for like decades and see who gets more jacked like 20 years later. So we can't necessarily know or predict that but life is going to you know probably like in I've never deliberately like aggressively bulked or cut I have like gradually gained weight primarily for strength performance not necessarily with any hypertrophy you know goals myself but then like you know hospital work gets tough and I unintentionally cut because shit happens and so I've kind of effectively ended up in that situation just as a result of life but yeah it's all I've had. === FILE: Is Training To Failure A Good Idea？ [6OwaUlX4Qic].txt ===

Hi there, any general guidelines for training with RPE, particularly in regards to how often and what context RP-10 can be considered a productive training stress? As far as are any guidelines, I'm not aware of any practice guidelines for RP-10s when he's RP-9 when he's RP-8. As far as my general recommendation, my assault based on coaching and using RP-E to communicate how hard things should be with people for, oh, I don't know, a better part of the last six years, almost exclusively. I rarely program RP-10s outside of a testing situation or meet situation because I just don't think it's worth it. Meaning that I don't think that the fatigue is worth the potential stimulus that you get out of that. I think that most efforts should be somewhere in that RPE 6 to 8 range in general. That doesn't mean you never go to 9 or you never do a set at 5, but it just means in most of the sets I think should be RP-6 to 8, and that's as far as a general guideline. That's as close as I can get. The rep schemes can obviously vary across that, but I don't know that I just spend too much time working well below RP-6 or well above RP-8. Maybe here and there, but not yet a lot. Yeah, I tend to agree. I think that hopefully what you guys took away from the programming lecture is we're aiming to deliver a stimulus to the individual to elicit a response. The weight we put on the bar is exclusively selected as a strategy to get a particular response out of somebody. One metric of that internal load, that response that we're looking for is RPE. I don't know that I really almost ever in a training context want to elicit a 10 out of 10 situation, because the closer you get to that 10 out of 10 effort, you may be getting incrementally greater stimulus, but I think the rate that the fatigue cost goes up way faster. Unless there is some particular reason why the performance on that set in that session matters a lot, which I can't really think of too many situations without the case, then it's probably not worth the cost. I mean, there are some, sometimes where you're just going for some arbitrary PR because you want to. Like I can think of the time, the first, when I last fall, I squatted 500 for 10. I thought you were going to say two days ago. No. No. But that time, I was only supposed to squat it for 8, and I squatted it for 8, and I was like, I think I got 10, and 10 would just be cool to do, so I'm just going to do this. But I would not program that ahead of time to say, I'm going to go to 10 today because I think that this is a valuable training stress. That was an excessive amount of fatigue generated from that session, and I wouldn't say I would regret doing it, but I wouldn't have programmed it ahead of time. You could make a case for going closer to failure on isolation type movements that has been discussed. Still don't think that you need to go to 10. But when you're talking about general guidelines for training with RPE, I think that we can get a reasonably good training stimulus staying further away from failure on our compound movements along with specific practice for your task, like single at 7, single at 8, double at 7, double at 8, et cetera. But for isolation stuff, you can go closer to failure because in general, this systemic fatigue you're going to get out of it, right? Taking your tricep press downs to failure or something like whatever. It's not going to be that big of a deal. Thought is that if you let people go to failure to RPE 10, that helps them calibrate their RPE scale. I know that it is unargument. I just think it's relatively weak because I don't necessarily care how accurate the RPE rating is. Just as long as you're using the same scale each time, so the precision is still high. But you know, that is unargument. Sure. Okay. Yep.

Which interesting is these discussions have been ongoing for a number of decades despite like the popularity of some narratives that are ongoing about how to talk about this stuff with patients. And so I have quote here pulled up because I had the benefit of like preemptively reading these questions ahead of time and this is from one of walls articles in 1979. And he says pain is taken not as not as a simple sensory experience signaling the existence of damage tissue the presence and intensity of pain is to poorly related to the degree of damage to be considered such a messenger. Pain is a poor protector against injury since it occurs far too late in the case of seven injury or a very slow damage to provide useful preventative measure. Instead is proposed that pain signals the existence of a body state where recovery and recuperation should be initiated. This places the word pain in the same class of words such as thirst and hunger which signal not only a body state but also signal the impending onset of a former behavior. Pain is a way of being in the world as Bork said it is specific to the individual's existence and I often look at as a call to action as an imperative. But it often to what wall is saying occurs way too late in those experiences is reflective in nature. And it's not going to alarm us to something impeding because you're reflecting on what's already happened typically in the scenarios. I would I highly recommend folks go read walls article is quoting on the relation of injury to pain the John Bonic Electra that's from 1979. Also highly recommend casser's paper which is on just titled the function of pain by casser c a s s e r. It will probably challenge some people's biases about like evolutionary adaptations of pain which is a common narrative that goes with pain is an alarm. I am far less confident in the narrative of evolutionary adaptation as an affordance than I was before I read that paper. I think it takes care of most of those questions. The adaptations that you're leaning from, the endurance training are going to impede or attenuate or otherwise interact with negatively the adaptations you're seeking from the resistance training. It's usually not so much that endurance folks are afraid of the adaptations from resistance training, impeding the adaptations they're selecting by engaging in a lot of endurance training. And I understand that I'm not famous. But I think we can do it. I think we can do it. So tell your friends. Connor Whitty, how do you manage fatigue when doing full body training? So this probably gives us a good chance to talk about fatigue, what it is, and then like how do I think about it in general. So fatigue in general are the negative psychological and physiological things that occur secondary to an exercise stimulus. There are two broad categories of fatigue. One is peripheral. Those things happen at the level of the muscle. So muscle damage, accumulation of metabolic, waste products, depletion of energy substrate. All the things would fall under the umbrella of peripheral fatigue. And then there's a central fatigue, which basically is a reduction of the neurological signal to the muscle to create force happens at the level of the brain or spinal cord. And so together, those things are fatigue. And again, they're the negative sort of psychological and physiological things that occur secondary to exercise stimulus. As far as what causes greater fatigue out of proportion to the exercise stimulus, which I think is what you're really getting at, sets to failure tend to be very, very fatiguing, compared to sets where there are one or more repetitions left in reserve. The level exercises tend to be more fatiguing that exercises that you've either done before or exercises that you've done similar variations to, that secondary to the repeated bout effect. Other things that tend to be, again, more fatiguing out of proportion to the exercise stimulus tend to be really heavy. High RPE type work at really high load. So for example, if the general intensity range that drives strength improvements is somewhere between 60 to 80 percent on average, that's where most of your volume work will be done just due to the nature of being able to complete a lot of repetitions in that sort of range. It's not that 80 percent doing sets of four, for example, or five, whatever, at 80 percent gives you a greater strength benefit than doing sets of four or five at 70 percent, for example. But it does cost you more fatigue. So when you think about trying to drive the sort of signal to build fitness adaptations up, you'd want to do more sets higher volume and not necessarily incur a bunch of unwanted or unnecessary fatigue on this case, meaning extraneous. So working heavier is not always better. I don't think that full body training is necessarily more fatiguing than body part or exercise, like a split programs, sort of fatigue. I think fatigue is really unique to the individual and what they've done historically and what they're used to, what their expectations are and in addition, like all the individual characteristics that make them them. So the exercise stimulus is what it is. It gets filtered through again, all the things that make you, you, and then on the other side is the stress which drives both fitness adaptations and fatigue. So how do I think about fatigue? I think about fatigue is sort of a necessary thing that occurs as, you know, again, fitness adaptations go up. Fatigue is also going to go up ideally not in proportion. Ideally, the fitness adaptations outstrip the amount of fatigue that's occurring and therefore you get better. Your best performances will not occur in general when fatigue is at its lowest. So for example, you could go on vacation, right? Take a week off and you're fatigue, particularly from training is going to go way way down. You slept a bunch, you didn't exercise, you didn't train, you ate a bunch of food, all as well, but when you come back to the gym, you don't usually PR. Why? Because your fitness adaptations have decayed. So I don't know that I would be trying to minimize fatigue all the time. Rather, I think a better focus is to try to maximize fitness adaptations and fatigue will tend to trend down over time as you do workouts that are similar to ones you've done before. I would accommodate to what you've previously done. That's what tends to drive this sort of fitness adaptation accumulation that is at a greater rate than the amount of fatigue that you're incurring. So this is why you see in general high-perchary results occur a few weeks after the onset of training rather than the initial onset of training, you kind of have to get used to the training, same thing with strength improvements. So I just wouldn't worry about fatigue like from a recovery standpoint rather I worry about load and fatigue management within the context of a program based on what you've been doing so far. Yeah, well, so the first part of this strength is specific to context to how it's trained, you know? So if you, for instance, if you only train sets of 10, then you're likely to get the biggest payoff, the biggest transference, the biggest carryover to like a 10-ret max or heavy set of 10. So one, there's this thing called a warm-up effect, or basically you're kind of tentative on the first rep because you're either low-key afraid or scared, then maybe it's going to hurt, and you're not really allowing all of your volitional motor units to kind of fire with maximum force. You kind of have a break on you, a restrictor plate, if you will. The, this was, this is a made up muscle. It doesn't actually exist based on any criteria we have anatomically. This was made up by a physical therapist in the 60s looking at four recently amputated legs. They found that there were fibers at the end of the Vassus Medialis, which is one of the muscles of the quadriceps. They found that the distal end of it right by the knee had these Oblique running fibers and they called it the VMO. Actually later, petitioned Namananatamica, which at the time was responsible for naming all these muscles. They petitioned that group to actually say that there was a VLO as well. So they were trying to not only add a muscle to the sort of dictionary of muscles and the VMO, they were also going to add the VLO and then they wanted to rename the quadriceps to the sexist ups because now there are six heads anyway. None of that worked. The VMO is not a real muscle. Cramps generally, I guess you could maybe call it a sign of not recovering well because it just means that fatigue was relatively high unless there's some medical condition, but most of the most folks keep cramping is just a little bit too much fatigue. Doesn't mean anything if it goes away. If it just happens when you stand up from your desk and then it goes away. It just could be positional. I don't know, wouldn't really worry about it. Can leg press and RDL replace the squat and deadlift if the only goal is high-purchary. Yeah, sure can. Sure can. I would actually argue that the RDL is probably better for high-purchary the hamstrings and potentially even glutes than the deadlift. I mean, really again, which you're looking for is range of motion. The ability to progressively overload via adding weight and reps volume being more important here than absolute intensity. And then the ability to do a bunch of reps and sets without getting too fatigued. So you think about like, how, you know, what could you do more of in a given week or a given session without incurring way too much fatigue that would overwhelm the system and compromise your high-purchase response to the training. Leg press is going to be better in a squat RDL. Since it's a little lighter, you know, but you still have a really long range of motion range of motion is very similar, especially for the hamstrings and glutes and erectors. It's probably a better choice from a fatigue standpoint, although, you know, I could argue it's not that much different, but it may be a little bit, maybe a little bit better. And then people really get worked up about what you can use more weight on the squat. Well, not really than a leg press, but, you know, then a leg extensions, like, a little shore, but the question isn't how much absolute weight can you use? The question is how much motor unit recruitment can you get? And we know that, you know, doing sets of, you can get the same amount of motor unit recruitment doing sets of five and sets of 30. You know, just it, as long as you're willing to go near to the near failure, the question isn't, you know, how much motor, you know, recruitment can you get by the second rep of a set. Question is how much total motor unit recruitment did you get at the end of a whole set? How many reps were stimulating the sort of muscle growth? And then how many of those sets can you do in a given week and to give a session? So anyway, I think people try to overly complicate this high-purchasing thing, and really what you need to do is pick exercises that have a big range of motion can be loaded or done for enough reps that generate that stimulate motor unit recruitment and then that you can do enough volume of them to continue to drive high-purchreat for you over time. Is there evidence to show a salt craving is relevant to actual hydration slash electrolyte imbalance? So those are completely different things. Hydration and electrolyte imbalance, although sometimes they happen. Same time. Gen general people, the thirst response to exercise or sweating in an active environment tends to be a little delayed. And then final thing just off the cuff without knowing anything more about you would be when was the last time you were able to do that activity without knee pain and then kind of what's changed since then. So most of the time knee pain when with respect to cycling is generally due to end actually with resistance training is usually a load management problem. I mean load when I say load I don't mean weight. That's part of the external load, external load would be objective metrics things like load range of motion, velocity, total volume, etc. What I mean is internal load. So internal load is the load that's actually placed upon the lifter or the individual which is the external load that's filtered through the individual characteristics of the person. So their previous training, their preparedness to train, their motivation to train, their expectations about what the training is going to feel like and what it's going to do to them. Environmental stress which is not just like humidity, temperature, wind, whatever would like, what's going on in your life, all these things, genetics, again it sort of filters the external load to determine the internal load which is ultimately what gets transmitted into either fatigue or fitness adaptations. And so if you're having a bunch of pain that's cropped up out of nowhere I think the road that I go down is load management and see kind of what do we need to do to get you back in the game and then as far as practically how to do that usually backing off external load which in this case would be intensity, volume and things of that nature in addition to education would be kind of the first steps there. Using a belt is one of them the data right now suggests that using a belt increases bar velocity and improves the efficiency basically keeping the bar path a little more a little strater. So as far as can you be a very strong individual in there and never use a belt. Sure you'll just likely lift less weight than if you used a belt and got good at using the belt. Yes, I'll refer you to the beginner prescription, or, uh, uh, which is the free version of our beginner template, uh, the beginner template also comes with like a 70 page ebook that really details how we came up with that program, which includes a section on exercise selection. So there's no such thing as general strength. All strength is specific. It's specific to the rep range you train it in, it's specific to the range emotion, the velocity, the contraction types, all sorts of things. The degree that one exercise improves performance in another exercise is called transference, uh, or carryover. And the more closely related to exercises are via those again, uh, the range emotion, the contraction type, velocity, etc. Uh, the more closely that they're, they're, or the more likely they're going to carry over to each other. So, uh, for a general trainee, the person who's not going to go compete in a barbell sport, instead of specializing on a few exercises, I would like to have a broader base of physical development that I would build for them until they wanted to specialize if they did. So I would not just use one type of squat variation, or even really mandate that they squat. I really just want loaded hip and knee movement, all right? Like, uh, so same thing with the deadlift. I wouldn't necessarily make sure that they do a conventional deadlift or similar deadlift. They could do a trap bar deadlift, you know? Um, yeah. So I have way less restriction. And then finally, we know that from a motor learning standpoint, when you're trying to actually learn, um, how to move your body, for instance, at space, and, and develop all these motor programs, um, particularly when it comes to non-standard, uh, or movements that are different each time, um, that you would want a wider variety of movements. People learn faster that way, and people have more robust development, uh, of these motor programs. So wouldn't high-press specialized just from a, uh, a sort of, uh, training development standpoint, want more proficiency in more movements, rather than proficiency in less movements. And then, I also think people learn better that way. So hopefully that makes sense. And she will bug Pester, one of us for the answer. Yes, true. OK. Question number one. Smoking is associated with obesity and central adiposity. But smokers often cite fear of weight gain as a barrier to smoking cessation. What do? Yeah. Well, so I understand where this comes from, because the idea, and again, there's nuggets of truth in here that nicotine is like an appetite to suppress it. People have this habitual process of smoking them after meals. And they feel like that helps them curb their hunger, et cetera. And then every time they've tried to quit, it is common for individuals who quit smoking that they start eating more in the short term. That being said, amongst smokers, people who smoke, who are heavy smokers, tend to have higher rates of obesity. You also pulled the study. Yeah, I pulled a, I did some background research while I was back there sifting through these. And this paper by Dair in 2015, they looked at almost 500,000 people in the UK who were smokers. So pretty substantial population size that they looked at there. And I'll just quote this line from it. Said amongst smokers, the risk of obesity increased with the amount smoked. And former heavy smokers were more likely to be obese than former light smokers, about a 60% higher odds of that. And they said, risk of obesity fell with the amount of time from quitting. After 30 years, former smokers still had high risk of obesity than current smokers, but the same risk as people who had never smoked. So that increase in kind of tendency towards gaining weight after quitting smoking. That seems to be a transient thing after quitting. But the further out you get from successfully quitting smoking, the more your obesity risk tends to normalize and kind of merges with the same risk of somebody who had never smoked at any point in their life. So I would not use this as a reason to not smoke or to not quit smoking. Although it is cited as a barrier commonly, you know, that risk normalizes after, you know, longterm. Yeah, it's like a short-term risk. In addition with some of the medical sort of management, we have with the associate's smoking cessation and some of the other psychological techniques exceed the CBT and stuff, that those tend to be having better outcomes with respect to even that short-term risk of increase in weight. === FILE: Not Losing Weight In A Calorie Deficit, What Do？ [MYU2KfmS9Pg].txt ===

Music Music New client reports eating below their total daily energy expenditure, but isn't losing weight, what do? I imagine we can't instantly correct under reporting. Specifically, do you still prescribe an amount of calories that should result in weight loss per the NIH, if they report a total daily energy intake lower than the prescription? So basically, somebody say, I'm eating these calories, but I'm not losing weight, what do? So just like I was talking about in the nutrition lecture yesterday, if the first you check the adherence, right? So it's like, hey, look, are you sticking to this plan? And they say yes. And you're like, okay, cool. And you're taking them at their word, and they're not losing weight at that calorie level, I would reduce calories, and a story. If you do that again, and they're still not losing weight, I kind of go through the same process again. We've just reduced another 250 to 500 calories. They're reporting being buried adherent, and still not losing weight. At that point, when I check for adherence, so let's say two weeks have gone by, they still have a loss weight. Ask them, hey, how's your adherence been? Any issues? We talk about it. I usually ask for proof, not in a way like I'm being an investigator here or interrogating them, but I want to see like there. My fitness path log or however they're tracking their food or something like that, just to kind of make sure that they're counting things correctly. Maybe there's not some sort of error. I also check for things that people don't tend to count certain condiments, sugar sweeten beverages, alcohol, stuff like that. Issues think that people have trouble logging. They're like, yeah, I don't log any of my coaxes because it's liquid. So you'd be surprised. And I mean, you know, this obviously happened sometimes otherwise I wouldn't have the story, but that alcohol and condiments tend to be like the three biggest offenders there for things that people don't track and then snacks. Like, you know, are you snacking on stuff in between meals? And you know, again, this is all in the context of somebody who's trying to lose weight and we've just lowered calories and still doesn't work. And so if nothing appears odd there, then I lower calories again. I'm not averse to continue to lower calories unless I suspect there's this really big adherence issue, you know. Now, obviously we had a client for a while who was, you know, over 200 pounds and then was reporting not losing weight at 1200 calories, but reported 7 out of 7. Every day she was very adherent. And I was like, well, let me see, I'd love to see the my fitness pal reports. I was like, oh, yeah, they're on my phone. I don't know how to get them to you. And I was like, well, you know, you just take them screenshots and just let them see them see what you're eating. It's like, it seems like a long process. Like, I don't know that I can get them to you. There was some resistance. And I got it. And so the whole thing wasn't to be like, gotcha ha ha ha. You know, there's the issue. The thing was like, well, let's address the actual problem. Right. What are the, you know, what sort of barriers do we have to adherence? And we had an even barrier to admitting there was a problem with adherence. So again, the thing isn't gotcha. The thing is, all right, we have an issue here. What's, how do we address the communication thing first and then figure out strategies to overcome the adherence issue? So that's how I address the issue and just some common things that I've seen over time. Austin, you have anything to add? I don't have anything to add to that. All right. Thank you.

=== FILE: Should Old People Take Steroids？ [3o4uwSEsvbE].txt ===

Okay. Should the elderly be prescribed anabolic steroids? So there are actually some situations where anabolic steroids have been researched for medical use. This includes severe burns because burn patients, whole body burns and things like that is a major hyper-cathabolic state. So there's some research in that world. And other syndromes where there is severe muscle and fat wasting, syndrome called Kekcia. So anabolic steroids have also been researched in like HIV-AIDS related Kekcia where these patients are just literally skin and bones. They've wasted away. So this is being looked at. I think part of the reason outside of the obvious social stigma around this stuff that they're not kind of used more liberally in practice is actually when you look at the available research that we have on this stuff in elderly patients, the outcomes are actually not like mind-blowingly good. And so I think that until such point as that evidence would emerge where we put an elderly individual presumably sarcopenic individual, not just somebody who's elderly for the sake of it, on anabolic if we see fantastic results in terms of quality of life or other kind of positive outcome measures, then I wouldn't expect medical societies or organizations to recommend this stuff until we have a solid evidence based to stand on. Think a big part of it is that that doesn't actually exist yet. And I'm actually open to the possibility that they may not deliver the benefits that we all assume they would. Rather, I think that we should pull the levers that we know work right now, getting physical activity up and getting the nutritional intake to where it should be. And I definitely think it's reasonable for us to research this stuff. But going back to the root of the question should the elderly be prescribed anabolic steroids? At this time, no, that's not wouldn't be my recommendation because we don't have clear evidence of consistent benefit whereas there is some potential for harm, particularly in elderly who, again, remember the number one cause of death in the US in the world that I talked about on day one yesterday is cardiovascular disease. And there are cardiovascular risks associated with these medications. If you were to give them to patients, so we're giving them medications with some known risk from a cardiovascular standpoint and potentially other organ systems that can be evolved. They're involved. There can be side effects on the liver depending on the type of antibiotics deride and the route of administration as well as on the kidneys. And a few other kind of potential side effects and complications for unclear benefit. So we need research to demonstrate clear benefit before we're going to comfortably prescribe it and that really stands. In my opinion for any medical intervention that we're going to do, I would prefer to have good evidence of benefit before I do it. And that has been particularly relevant recently with COVID when it comes to deciding how we're going to treat these patients. Yeah, I won't get good evidence before I decide to give somebody particularly medication that has known risks and unknown benefits. Yeah, I feel similarly mainly with respect to the, obviously the respect of it analysis, but with the existing data on this. If there was robust data showing like, yeah, when you give elderly patients testosterone, they grow huge muscles and their quality of life improves and all this other stuff improves, then I think it would already be widely adopted. Right now you have, you know, a relatively few amount of studies, particularly looking at muscle wasting and muscle in fact combined wastey diseases. So like Austin said, HIV burn patients, other diseases that causes cakexia like liver disease, et cetera. And then a few like fringe papers that like randomly pop up like using testosterone and women who have chest pain like angina. Pretty easy. Yeah, I remember that one. Yes, we were. Or now the most recent paper that came out of this is testosterone use and depression. And there's other papers obviously out there on testosterone, but much fewer on other antibiotic agents, right? So people are talking about like, oxygen, gelone or anovar, decandurable, whatever. This is the same case that Psalms the selective androgen receptor modulators, these are the new drugs that are on the street, well they're on the street right now, but they're being researched. These are effectively, they're supposed to be like steroid analogs, like work like steroids, but have none of the side effects because they're selective for the receptors that they actually bind to. But unfortunately during the phase two clinical trials when they're doing using them on these older people, they're not getting the benefits that are purported like bigger muscles, stronger muscles, being able to be more active or anything like that. And so when you have this data that like overall suggests not a reliable benefit, and then there are known risk factors, it makes sense that the medical community is kind of like, even during our board's prep, I remember on like step one, there was a question about using anabolic steroid, like a patient who was using anabolic steroids, and then like one of the lines was, data that, at present, does not show or shows that anabolic steroids don't provide a performance benefit in sport, please counsel the patient accordingly. And I was like, uh, Vinny down the street at gold, might have been a video. So as far as how this works in the future, I think if better data comes out, that of a useful, in order to get that better data, we need to do more studies. And I think that in general medicine is fairly liberally leaning, liberal leaning, and so as new data emerges, I don't know that any stigma is going to prevent us from like adopting the latest practices provided ample evidence exists. There was a big series of studies that came out, uh, think maybe last year or two years ago called the testosterone trials. It was a big set of multiple studies on testosterone for various outcomes. So if you're interested in this topic, I'll just look up, look, that was up, and get some results. Yep.

=== FILE: Should Older Individuals Gain Weight to Gain Muscle？ [3quGzNFuDWg].txt ===

Question number one, if an elderly individual who is at a healthy weight, but under muscle starts resistance training, should they be eating a caloric surplus to build muscle, given that they are eating enough protein? Well, okay, this is a good question. In general, I don't know that I recommend anybody for weight gain, unless they want to. So if their personal preference is, I'd like to gain weight for whatever reason. Either strength is the most important thing to them, and they have a, they have their room to grow. That's fine. They want to gain more muscle mass, just for their own record. That's fine, but just for like reducing the potential of bad health outcomes from happening, you can do that without gaining a substantial amount of body weight. And a person new to resistance training has a high likelihood of building a lot of lean body mass without increasing their body weight. We see that all the time in individuals with obesity, they simultaneously reduce their waste or comfort and body fat while increasing their lean body mass. And in particular, I don't know that gaining a bunch of weight at an elderly age is likely to be a great idea. Just because if they're already in a healthy, healthy weight as is kind of a qualifier in the question, I mean, I see a lot of elderly folks who are extremely underweight, you know, it's not often that I see individuals who are like have made it into their 80s with morbid obesity. Oftentimes they don't, they get kind of selected out a little bit earlier than that for through various mechanisms, things that we've talked about this weekend, the medical conditions that can arise. So oftentimes the people who make it that far tend to be pretty thin and frail on the other end of this spectrum in those situations, then getting adequate nutrition and putting them into a calorie surplus if we can, does become a priority. But if somebody is already at a healthy weight, then I would just lean on getting them to train rather than worrying about getting them in a calorie surplus. What you know, the internet's going to say, what? Don't you know that in elderly population, the class 1, OBSV has the lowest all-cosm mortality rates? How do you explain that? The question is saying that they're at a healthy weight, so then I would ask how we're defining healthy weight here. Sure. Well, what I'm getting is that it's that explanation, basically ignores, again, a few things that Dr. Baracky said. So individuals who tend to carry a lot of excess adipose tissue tend to get filtered out when we get to that elderly population, so they tend to make it that far. And those who do, there's obviously there's a survivor bias there. And in addition, once you become elderly, having a low BMI, so like in normal or particularly underweight represents either chronic illness or increase in frailty. And so both of those things, portend bad outcomes. We wouldn't necessarily want somebody who's got a normal BMI, or it is slightly in the lower realms of the overweight BMI range to necessarily say, I got to get my BMI to over 30 because that's going to reduce my risk of premature mortality or reduce disease burden. Yep. All right. Sick. We took on the internet. There you go. Boom.

All right, question number two. If hospitalized, should I have somebody bring me way protein? You know, this is a funny question. I'm not a silly question. I'm not like that. Yeah. Yeah, I mean, if I was hospitalized, I would try to eat more dietary protein. And I'm not saying that just because I'm like protein or gains. This is the thing is the risk of like critical illness, myopathy, bed rest, and it's effect on your antibiotic resistance. All those sort of factors, in addition to not training, would all put you up much higher risk for losing muscle tissue. And for most folks, especially those who don't have like a profound amount of extra muscle tissue to lose, having a concentrated source of dietary protein that is available to stimulate muscle protein synthesis.
