On the other hand, the counter argument that I make frequently, when we're talking about in hospital diets, because I am involved in making these decisions frequently, is that it's unlikely to make a big difference on people's long-term outcomes when most hospital stays or not going to be particularly long. If you're in an unfortunate situation where you're in the hospital for like three months, then sure, I can make an argument that it's going to make a big difference there. But I'll frequently, majority of the patients that I admit to the hospital are going to be in the hospital for three days or less. Most of them, and fewer, they're longer than that. And then the few of us are going to be there for like weeks to months on end. So somebody who's going to be in the hospital for a day or two days or three days, we're going to say, oh, they have heart disease. So we're going to put them on a heart healthy diet for a day in the hospital. And like, it doesn't really do anything. So I tend to not be super picky about that, because ultimately what it ends up is doing is just restricting the patients' choices when they're in the hospital. And they're already miserable enough. And there's no sense in my mind torturing them for something to give them like two meals that fit this criteria that really. So the bigger deal would be if we could get them to consume sufficient dietary protein in the weeks, months, and years leading up to the hospitalization. So they're super jacked when they go to the hospital. And they're at lower risk of in-hospital mortality. And arguably, they don't need to potentially go into the hospital all if the condition could have been averted. So I think that's far more important than worrying about an in-hospital diet because most hospital stays are relatively short. But to the extent they're going to be there for a while, as long as you don't have any reasons not to feed somebody's gut, then sure you can give them some protein. So they're going to be there for a while. If you were going to be in the hospital for seven days, you take it some way. Maybe I'm not going to be going out of my way to get it now. But you know, you know the range of ring these some way. Yeah, probably that strawberry junk junk keeps it in the back of your head. Yeah, I know.

It is really tender to the point of where I have you load, makes my knee feel like it's going to explode. I've tried rehabbing myself but no results, any tips for recovery or what to do or what to avoid would be great. Thank you for your time. Yeah. So we deal with knee issues pretty frequently, particularly knee issues that are suspicious for tendon opportunities. And so a classic, you're giving it a pretty classic history for something like this. Typically, you can involve a quadriceps tendon opportunity which tends to be a little bit more localized to both the knee cap or a patella tendonopathy that tends to be localized a little bit below the knee cap for most people. And they tend to experience their discomfort associated with the squat, oftentimes in the bottom portion or during the balance or during the ascent when there's a little bit more tension applied to that structure. And so the question is why do these things kind of get sensitized in the first place? And the pathogenesis or the pathophysiology of how tendonopathy is happening is pretty complex. And that's really within the scope of the question, but it's thought that when you kind of chronically overload the tissue, usually in a cyclical fashion above the level that it's adapted to handle for, you know, a certain period of time that things can get a little bit, can get sensitized there. Some histologic changes that can happen, some neurological changes that can happen. There's a bunch of changes that occur in the process of precipitating a tendonopathy. So the question is what do we do about it? And we view these overwhelmingly as load-based issues. And so the treatment approach to it is also going to have to be, it's going to have to target that same issue. So it's going to be a load-based way to approach the management of it. So we just put that up for us that we approach this by managing training loads of justing programming, sometimes exercise selection, things like that overwhelmingly over or will be considered more passive approaches to treating tendonopathy that you might see so things like needle-ing or whatever other types of instruments you use for your tendon. That overwhelmingly don't tend to work compared to sham interventions or placebo interventions. And even surgery, I would be writing up a review of a re-syn article that was published on the role of surgery in tendonopathy and it doesn't really appear to have a great role in it. So what I would do for you is it sounds like at some point along the line that you're training or in your programming, there was some period of overload to that those tissues that were beyond what they were adapted to handle for whatever reason. And the more you continue to try to push through that if it's not improving, you're just prolonging this process. And this is something I've had to learn in the hard way in the past where usually we expect that a lot of aches and pains that come about the course of training tend to get better on their own and in fact they often do. But sometimes they don't and particularly when they start to smell like a tendonopathy is going on, then frequently you really end up requiring a change in how you're managing your programming. And so what I would probably do initially is dial you far back on your intensity. Potentially even on your dose of training volume that you're doing, maybe maybe not depending on how much you're doing right now. And sometimes we also adjust frequency and typically the intervention that we'll do is we'll actually do something either two to three times a week with a non consecutive days to give kind of a day off in between. There's some evidence pertaining to you know how tendons regenerate and adapt to reorganize in this process that where that can be beneficial. And really we need to we don't need to train in a point where there is no discomfort whatsoever. But the threshold or the kind of the decision process that we take here is if your symptoms are tolerable during the training session and they're not markedly exacerbated afterwards or for the 24 hours 36 48 hours afterwards. Then it's probably a reasonable stress dose. The question is how much do you increment it and this is where people frequently get this wrong. Is they want to get back to their prior level of function much more quickly than is realistic. So standard 10 and off the protocols tend to take a minimum of about 12 weeks or so for most kind of standard prescriptions or the studies on the matter. So you're going to have to set expectations early that this is the process you're going to have to commit to your increments are going to have to be small. You know rules of thumb that we use in practice is generally no more than 10% increments from session session oftentimes. I'll pull things even back further than that about you five percent increment from session session early on. But you're talking about loading load absolute load correct. Not like just reps. And then those small increments and try to build momentum and chalk up one win at a time each session. So the cost of investment would be lifetime effort and potentially money if I'm playing someone else just statically stretch me. And then what's the return on that and right now the return just doesn't seem meaningful enough to put time into it. And so I wouldn't do it because we're going to have a negative out of that for those athletes. Specifically, it doesn't reduce the risk for injury. Yeah, interestingly, some data actually shows that it increases the risk for injury. Yeah. And so those are the kind of the two big ones and the third one people are like, oh, well, jobs and it turns out we actually have a copper review on that and it's no positive benefit for delayed onset muscle soreness in a meaningful way. Question number two is actually on to particular cancer. And so we're going to cover some of the nuances of that particular condition and then expand it towards training, considerations for cancer patients in general. So let's start off with the question is from Steven. He says I was recently diagnosed with testicular cancer at 24 years old and went through an orchieth academy of one of my testicles this past week. I was wondering what the long term effects of this may cause for my strength pursuit with only one testicle going forward. Is this going to limit my ability to gain and maintain muscle slash strength at all? Should I look into T RT treatments? Any feedback would be much appreciated. This is a great place to actually say that none of this constitutes medical advice. This is all for infotainment purposes. You should definitely follow up with your doctor with respect to management, treatment, an evaluation of any medical condition. So this is more of a discussion in general sense. So again, I'm not your doctor. This is not constitute medical advice. Please follow up your own provider. So with that in mind, let's talk about this in a more general sense. So when orchieth academy is a surgical procedure to actually remove one or both testicles one is called a unilateral orchieth academy and then if both are moved that say bilateral orchieth to me. Similarly, this is the initial treatment for most testicular cancers and then also tends to be diagnostic in that you get to send the tissue off for pathology and then further evaluate the patient for staging. And any event the survival rates pretty good, five years of average, greater than 95% were pretty good at treating this sort of stuff. So after the orchidectomy, we have some good news and some bad news. The good news is most of these cancers are curable. In fact, the five years survival rates greater than 95%. The bad news is that your risk of having low testosterone is significantly increased with a unilateral orchieth academy where we remove one testicle. And the risk of low testosterone is even higher for those undergoing bilateral orchieth and we're both testicles removed because you're removing the specialized tissue that produces testosterone, the light excels in the testies. Dr. Gilligan of the American Society of Clinical Anthropology says we can cure about 19 out of 20 cases of testicular cancer, but a significant number of testicular cancers survivors have low testosterone and economic other aspects of health. So we look at a study on 1200 men who all had testicular cancer, how do unilateral orchieth academy? And you compare them to 200 matched controls, age matched controls. And you look at the sort of risk of male hypogonetism. It was increased by almost fourfold in those who had the unilateral orchieth academy and the risk was increased with the intensity of treatment. So increase amounts of chemotherapy, radiation, or additional surgical procedures all can't confer increased risk. So the question then becomes, what do you do with this information? And this is really similar to the recommendation we give towards the general population. If you have physical signs of male hypogonetism, it should be assessed properly via appropriate testing and additional medical history gathering. So these symptoms would include decreased vigor and libido, depressed mood, decreased muscle mass, and body hair actually less common takes much longer time for those things to manifest. And there are additional signs and symptoms that your doctor will work you up for. These are all non-specific symptoms, meaning that they don't always correlate to a low testosterone. And so what you would do if you have these symptoms is just talked to your doctor about them and you would be evaluated appropriately. Now if you have a patient who's recently undergone a unilateral orchieth academy, then you might be a little bit more vigilant about, hey, I need to monitor this a little bit more closely compared to somebody you hadn't had that procedure. For more information on male hypogonetism, I've actually linked an article from Dr. Baraki in the description below so you guys can check that out. So shifting away from specifically testicular cancer to the more general question of cancer and exercise, what do? There's an interesting trend for people with cancer actually decreasing their physical activity. So 75% of individuals report decreasing their physical activity levels after the diagnosis whereas only 4% report increasing their physical activity after the diagnosis. So the main predictors of people decreasing their physical activity after a cancer diagnosis are undergoing chemotherapy, being diagnosed with metastatic disease or having undergo surgery. And similar to other diseases, it's very important for those with cancer to actually maintain or increase their physical activity levels to meet the sort of minimum requirements. We'll look at mortality and cancer and physical signs that predict a poor outcome, weight loss history, loss of muscle mass, loss of muscle size. So looking at a study on about 1500 individuals, either GI or lung cancer, if individuals had all three of these poor, prognostic variables, they survive for about 8.4 months, regardless of their BMI so that means it doesn't matter if they were obese, if they were overweight, normal weight or underweight and if they had none of those features, their average survival was about 28 and a half months. And I think a lot of that comes back to having increased anaabolic resistance. So when you think about anaabolic resistance, that just means a sub normal response to anaabolic stimuli, dietary protein for example, training for example or the hormonal milieu. So testosterone and other anaabolic hormones. So when you think about individuals with cancer who are undergoing treatment, they have a lot of things that are actually promoting anaabolic resistance like chemotherapy, which causes inflammation, mitochondrial dysfunction, fatigue, weight loss, radiation therapy, has systemic effects, again, making people tired, weight loss, et cetera. And they might also be on medications like that deprived them of angergen, so reducing hormonal concentrations in the case of this bilateral or kiectomy for example or other conditions. Whether it might be taking glucocorticoids, which also promote anaabolic resistance. On the other side of this, we have tools that we can promote anaabolic sensitivity. So the first sort of arrow in our quiver would be resistance training. There's a dose response relationship between the amount of training that you can get somebody to do and their improvement in strength, in lean body mass, in skeletal muscle index, all of these things. One of the problems with recommending exercise in cancer patients who do tend to be older is that it's underdosed. And when we look at this choosing wisely initiative, which is from the American Board of Internal Medicine, and in this particular case, supported by the American Physical Therapy Association, they specifically say, do not underdose strength training programs for older adults. And instead match the frequency intensity and duration of the exercise to an individual's abilities and goals. What we'd like to do, again, is to increase the amount of resistance training, increase the amount of total physical activity that these people are doing to start combating some of that anaabolic resistance. The second strategy we have, or the second arrow in our quiver, is to engage in a dietary change that would overcome some of those anaabolic resistance. So right now, the RDA for protein intake in the United States is 0.8 grams of protein per kilogram body weight per day. However, this fails to account for anaabolic resistance and protein quality. And contrast to the RDA, the European Society for Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism actually published in different guidelines for healthy aging and adults, and also specifically makes mention of cancer patients. And so they're recommended protein intake is 1.2 to 2.0 grams per kilogram body weight per day, which is almost double that of the RDA. The idea is that the amount of essential amino acids that are concentrated in a meal, and that includes the branch channel amino acids, specifically loose-scene. The idea is that you'd want enough of those per meal in order to overcome this anaabolic resistance so that you can maintain or even improve muscle mass and skeletal muscle index and skeletal muscle function and prevent some of that weight loss associated with cancer treatment. That's 1.2 to 2.0 grams per kilogram body weight per day, which breaks down to 0.4 to 0.66 grams of protein per kilogram body weight per meal. And so the benefits of engaging in this resistance training and increase in dietary protein obviously increase lean body mass, increase muscle strength, increase muscle function in cancer patients. You get a reduction in cancer related fatigue, improvement in their quality of life. You also get increased rates of chemotherapy completion, meaning that individuals who are undergoing the physical activity changes and the dietary changes are actually able to complete all of their chemotherapy course, which is obviously beneficial for other cancer outcomes. And then finally, there's a reduced risk of cancer-specific and all-cause mortality for individuals who are engaging in these physical activity guidelines. So what are the recommendations? The 2018 Physical activity guidelines for Americans suggested on 2 to 3 days per week, adult should perform resistance exercises of moderate or greater intensity for each of the major muscle groups. They also suggest that individuals obtain 150 to 300 minutes of moderate intensity aerobic training or 75 to 150 minutes of vigorous intensity aerobic training. And for a more thorough discussion on that, we would recommend that you read our free beginner prescription text. We talk about that extensively in there. This recommendation is also supported by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. That'll be instead there are some special populations that we should make specific considerations for when we're talking about exercise programming. So for instance, there are treatment related complications such as lymphedema. It's basically swelling that occurs in an arm or leg or sometimes both arms, both legs, usually due to removal or damage to the lymph nodes as part of cancer treatment. That being said, we do have data suggesting that high intensity resistance training is safe in this population. That doesn't mean we should ignore that somebody has lymphedema, but rather we can encourage them to exercise and then manage the actual training based on the symptoms that they have during the exercise. There's also a concern for fracture in cancer is that either invade the bone from a primary tumor or from a metastatic cancer. However, early evidence suggests that resistance training is safe in metastatic prostate cancer. And there's established safety and efficacy of high intensity resistance training in other conditions where there's bone loss such as osteoporosis. That being said, we probably shouldn't ignore that somebody has this condition, but rather be cautious and monitor symptoms over time, adjust training as needed. And there are a whole host of other side effects that may be caused by cancer treatment, for instance peripheral neuropathy, which is basically an issue in the nerves carrying the signals from the brain or spinal cord to the muscles they can become damaged due to the medications. This is called chemo-induced peripheral neuropathy. That being said, there's actually evidence suggesting that exercise may reduce the peripheral neuropathy symptoms. And despite the sort of widespread relief that physical activity is not safe for those with peripheral neuropathy, there's substantial evidence, particularly from diabetic patients, suggesting that exercise is not only safe, meaning that they don't have an increased risk of injury, but actually is, again, beneficial to those with peripheral neuropathy. This is definitely not an exhaustive list of all potential side effects that people can have from cancer-related treatments. That being said, the underlying premise here is that there's a known benefit of meeting these physical activity guidelines or exceeding them in this population. And so, combined that with the known risk of being sedentary and it appears that the risks probably outweigh the benefits, although, again, each case is going to be different and we would recommend that you have this conversation with your physician. Overall, though, we should be encouraging increased physical activity and dietary changes in this population. All right, so we talked about stretching and we talked about cancer and exercise. Now let's go to some of these form checks and see what we can do. All right, so we'll start up here with Col G. This is 370 for 5. === FILE: Training VLOG #36： Is It Safe To Go Back To The Gym？ [Okgj2QuY8nQ].txt ===

Hey everyone, welcome back to the Borble Medicine YouTube channel. We bring modern medicine to strength conditioning and strength conditioning to modern medicine. Underneath of the doctor Jordan Faggin mom and it has been a while since we've done one of these training vlogs. This is training vlog number 36. I don't even remember when the last one was, but we're back in action. We've got a gym, we're showing you how I built that. I'm going to answer one of your questions about going back to the gym now that some gyms are opening again. And then, you know, we're just going to watch me with weights. And hey, if you stay tuned to the end of the video, we're going to show you how to submit your own questions to be answered right here on the YouTube channel. Also, some ways to submit your videos for form checks right here on the bottom of the medicine YouTube channel. So, thanks for tuning in. Let's get to it. In some states, gyms are opening up again. Is it safe to go back? So, this is a very complicated topic. Let's see if we can provide some insight. As you guys all know, coronavirus has dominated the news and has also polarized most folks on this topic. Unfortunately, it's become very political and I'm trying to stay away from that on this YouTube channel. Anytime we've posted something that's controversial in any way, just the comment section, it's all over the place. So let's try to stay out of politics and we'll keep it in the science realm here. So a few thoughts on whether or not it's safe to go back to the gym with a little background that helps you guys realize how I formulated this answer. So shelter in place orders have likely mitigated the severity of the pandemic compared to what we would have experienced with unmitigated spread, although not without heavy costs of its own. This is not a long term solution, which would likely require a vaccine and or new treatments for the disease. So the next step is going to be a gradual easing of restrictions, which has already taken place in some countries like China, Italy and Spain and also in states like Georgia, Tennessee and others. Other states are likely to eventually open up some businesses, which includes gyms, thankfully, over the coming weeks as well. So what do? To start, I think I should make it clear that most, if not all of the health benefits from exercise, including introduction and hard disease, reducing blood pressure, reducing the risk of developing certain types of cancer, reducing the risk of developing depression, can likely be achieved using an at home workout program to the extent that an individual can meet or exceed the current physical activity guidelines. In other words, most folks probably don't need to go to a gym in order to see health improvements from exercise, though there are some who would clearly benefit from additional equipment availability either due to personal preference or needs in order to suit their current fitness levels. Unfortunately, most folks are either sedentary or insufficiently active, meaning that they don't meet the current physical activity guidelines that includes both aerobic and resistance training components. For perspective, the current data indicates that only about 10 to 20 percent of the global population meets the guideline recommended activity and insufficient activity is responsible for about one and every 10 deaths or over 5 million deaths per year. In other words, not only do we have a coronavirus pandemic, but we also have a physical and activity pandemic that's been going on for a very long time. So ideally, we would use this time when much of the world's population has some extra time and is turning into public health authorities to heavily promote exercise and dietary changes as part of a national health improvement campaign to not only combat COVID-19, but also reduce the global burden of disease due to physical and activity and obesity. Despite the potential efficacy of a home-based exercise program for health outcomes, many will understandably prefer to go to a gym for a variety of different reasons. And they want to know, is it safe? As is the case with most decisions in life, there are risks and benefits that should be considered on an individual basis. So on the one hand, the risks of going to the gym are pretty clear. Your risk of infection from others goes up the more people that you're around. Alternatively, you yourself may be an asymptomatic or prescientomatic carrier of COVID-19 and you could infect others inadvertently, although this risk is difficult to assess. In any case, some steps can be taken to reduce these risks by both you and the gym. From a personal standpoint, you can reduce your risk of infecting others by wearing a mask when you exercise. You can also refer to one that you wash regularly and you get bonus points if you add an additional layer of pantyhose around the outside that actually increases the surface area that protects some particles from entering or leaving. Additionally, you should stay at home if you're currently experiencing symptoms at all, which now includes cough, shortness of breath, fever, chills, headaches, muscle pain, sore throat or a new loss of taste or smell among others. Same goes for if you've been in close contact with someone who has these symptoms, even if they haven't been formally diagnosed with COVID-19. You would also recommend avoiding the gym for now if you're over the age of 50, or if you have medical problems such as high blood pressure, diabetes, harder lung disease or any condition that results in a compromised immune system. Unfortunately, while these individuals would likely stand to benefit the most from regular physical activity, which may be increased, given access to the gym, they are also at the highest risk of a medical complication secondary to COVID-19. Additionally, if you have regular contact with individuals who are over the age of 50 or who do have any of these medical problems, you're probably increasing their risk of a bad outcome from an infection with COVID-19 by being in regular contact with others. So we would recommend probably not going to the gym if that is something that you do. Gims can also reduce the risk of spreading the infection by increasing the amount of clean supplies available to its members, as well as increasing the number of scheduled cleanings that happen per day. They should also provide staff with adequate protective equipment, limit the number of patrons allowed at a given time, whether that's 25% of normal occupancy or 50% no one really knows, but limiting the number of people who can be at the gym at one time is likely a way to improve the ability to engage in social distancing while being in the gym. Also spreading equipment for their part so that people can be a separate from each other's probably a good idea. And again, requiring all individuals to wear a mask in order to enter the facility in addition to potentially screening folks who are coming in the gym. If you need to take the temperature or ask if they're symptomatic, all those things would increase the likelihood of picking up somebody who might be infectious and should likely not be able to get into the gym. So while there are certainly some risks and some ways to avoid those risks, it's reasonable in my opinion that young healthy individuals that do not have regular contact with their high risk groups and have access to a gym that's stepping up their health policies could probably go to the gym and minimize the amount of risk that they have. But again, there are no free lunches here. As with most things that pertain to this virus, these opinions will almost certainly change when new data becomes available. If you are looking for information on how to exercise at home, we have an article on this on our website. I've linked that in the description below. And if you're just about to get back into the gym after an extended break, I actually put out a little free template and some guidance on how to do that in our latest newsletter. I've linked that in the description below as well. Maybe we'll do a YouTube video on it if you guys choose that to be a topic that you're interested in. Okay, so look, that's my thoughts on hey, gyms are opening up what do. Let's talk about my training because you know, the barbell medicine, YouTube channels got to be a little bit about me at least just a little bit. So first off, what happened with the gym? How did I come into this sweet home gym set up? Well, first, I already had this alico bar. I've had it now for almost a decade. It is the competition IPF power lifting bar and I love it. It is my favorite barbell of all time. It's probably outside the budget of most folks. It's way, way expensive. I like the rogue Ohio power bar just fine, particularly the 20 kilo version, the stainless steel version, the Texas power bar is probably my favorite, non-alico bar of all time. But all, either of those would have been fine. I just already had this one so I didn't have to buy something. I did buy weights, the reason why I bought alico weights and not rogue weights because like I had them in stock and they shipped to me within two days. So that was great. That being said, the price point for the rogues make them hard to pass up. If you want calibrated kilo plates, but the like a one-to-do look nice. Also, I ended up borrowing a Texas strength systems combo racks and seemed like every place was sold out of regular rack or even a combo rack. But it's getting the job done so far. So I got, we have 330 kilos worth of weight, which is enough to train with. I picked up some horse doll mats from tractor supply company and I get people asking in the DMs all the time like, hey, do you actually need a wooden platform to lift on or can I just use horse doll mats? Well, you don't need a platform to lift on, but I will say it is much nicer to lift on. It reduces the reverberations from heavy dead lifts, trust me, and it's just overall feels a little bit better in my opinion. That being said, for the amount of time I think we're going to be spending training in storage unit or in this case a garage, I was cool with just using the horse doll mats, so that's working just fine. I'm not worried about damaging the concrete because I'm not dropping my dead lifts even though they are reasonably heavy. That's a weird flex, but okay. All right, so with that in mind, let's get into some of my form checks from the last three weeks. I tried to put everything in order for the videos that I had of the last three weeks, so basically all my comp squats, so week one, week two, week three, comp edge, week one, week two, week three, et cetera. Stuff like that so you guys can see the progression and again, this kind of mimics the template that I put together for like how to get back into gym from an extended layoff, maybe due to COVID-19. So first up, all right, this was in the storage unit. I, yeah, the first week I came back. These things felt really heavy in awkward because at this point it had been almost four weeks since I had squatted. So this is only 200 kilos. I basically wanted to work up to a set of four in RP7 or five in RP7. So depth looks pretty good. Now I can also see my toes, you especially see the left one here. four we're going to talk just a little bit about the order of operations in the way that the stroke works best number one I want you to take a look at the damper so when you come to sit down on the machine you need to make sure it's set for you and one of those things is making sure there's damper is set in the place where you want it to be set this is not the resistance when it's on a one that doesn't mean it's going to be the easiest when it's on a ten that doesn't mean it's going to be the hardest this is a variable resistance machine which means the resistance it gives you is based on the work you put into the machine this just represents the drag so it's pulling an air when it's at a one it's not pulling in in any air when it's at a ten it's pulling in a bunch of air I would suggest most people start with it between a three and a five that's a good place to start but definitely play around with it but also definitely just look at it before you start throwing it up at a ten doesn't mean you're going to get the most out of your workout number two where are you going to put your feet first of all don't row in your lifting shoes put on some regular old ten of shoes it doesn't matter just nothing with that lifted in the heel and the super rigid sole so when you put your feet in the straps you're going to put it so that the strap is over the widest part of your foot then you're going to pull those straps nice and tight so that straps going to sit over like the bottom of your shoelaces where the the widest part of your foot is and that's going to put your foot in the best position so that you can pick your heels up doesn't mean you need to but you can and it's going to put you in the best position to mechanically apply force to do each stroke number three how to sit on the seat seems really simple but there's actually a few things you can do that might make your whole stroke way better just by adjusting how you sit on the seat what i like to do is go ahead and straighten out your legs and reach over try and touch your feet it could be a nice stretch when you first sit on the machine but also it's just kind of a nice segue into picking your butt cheeks up so you're going to actually pick your butt cheeks up to kind of rotate your pelvis into a more neutral position so instead of sitting on the seat like this i'm going to adjust so everything rotates forward this is going to put me in a much better position to hinge from my hips and get more out of every stroke when it comes to rowing what we're trying to do is push through our legs and hang on this handle to produce force to make the machine move right make that flywheel inside push the air so starting up in that catch position which is this front position we're looking for a shin's vertical with the shoulders and front of the hips arms nice and long shoulders down chin up neck nice and long from this position think of using your biggest movers using your legs you're going to drive with the legs then swing the body open then pull the arms in so it's really simple mantra arms come away body comes over legs bend so it's a legs body arms arms body legs a lot of people like to skip that body swing right here and they don't end up in this body over position up at the front at the catch and so then they end up missing a lot of power from the legs as they drive it back so as you get started rowing once you're in that perfect position your feet are in the right place and then dampers in the right place then you just break it down and you row a little slower just for a little while all right and you get that legs body arms arms body legs and that's going to get you a much stronger stroke because when you're in this position you can push through your legs and transfer that force from the legs through your body into your arms into the machine all right so legs body arms arms body legs thinking about using the legs to drive to get the most out of your stroke and hopefully you'll have a much better time in your conditioning good luck hey dad hey do a man you ready to do this thing well I think we're going to be a little rusty but we'll make it work I'm more optimistic I think we're going to be fresh fresh yeah so this is the difference we've had a six month the six month dealer do you know what about it let it marinate had to probably explain the same things you know it doesn't times differently yeah it's great we'll be right are you more excited about doing this seminar than your 720 pull yesterday you don't have to be I think there are going to be diminishing returns at the high end of how much activity you're doing but if we can get some initial buy-in with a low amount that's fine we'll start there and then we'll see if we can nudge things in the right direction by continuing to work through that behavior change cycle what's keeping you from adding another day of activity what's keeping you from doing an additional session of the rubic activity right what are the pros and cons that play here is it because you work three jobs and you have five kids and you know you have real significant barriers to actually doing this or is it just that you haven't found an activity that you enjoy enough to do that much yet so not only is there no minimum threshold for benefit any amount is better than none but we see what is called a dose response relationship what that means is the higher the dose the higher the response you get with respect to training volume and health related benefits are our pre-existing ideas about pain and how it works right so if you are still stuck in the old school interpretation of what pain means where pain always means tissue damage right that's going to be more counterproductive you're not going to be able to function as well because anytime you experience any sentiment you're going to be like oh that means something that's happened right so you're pre-existing understanding can be problematic here and that's one of the avenues that we target when we're working with clients and patients we try to provide a lot of this education in a way as to reframe their ideas their beliefs and their understanding about pain and what it means and what they can do about putting them in charge of the situation building up that self-efficacy that they can actually benefit for example we talk about exercise technique we try not to talk about it in a way that unnecessarily makes exercise threatening in other words we don't say you must move this one perfect way otherwise you will develop pain that is unhelpful not only is it unhelpful if potentially harmful if people begin assigning threat value to exercise because you can't control how much threat they assign to it right this is where dead looks for bad for the back squads are bad for the knees comes from not only do people come to believe those but they come to believe that there's so dangerous and so threatening that the risk of doing those outweigh the potential health benefits of doing those things which is not the case right so we want to tilt the scales back again so people can say the benefits of doing these exercises far outweigh the risks in many situations regardless of the fine minute details of how I'm moving whether my knees are an inch forward or an inch back whether my back is a centimeter flex or a centimeter extended particularly if the loads that you're using are reasonable for the person

Um, work with a coach trying to get a little more shallow, a little more from the inside. And, uh, fix some nasty habits I picked up when I first picked up the game. I'll get about two years ago. But yeah, I can get around a course. Okay. And, uh, if you liked that, let me know in the comments below. Uh, let me know what you want to see next week. Um, for training this week. Because the time thing. Okay. So training from five weeks out will get to it just here in the middle of the day. Just here in a second. But first I want to talk about progressive loading versus progressive overload. So in the context of strength training, I think the central tenet of progressive loading is that you're able to increase the weight on the bar while keeping the rest of the program. All of the other constraints the same. That is the reps scheme, the volume, the rest periods, the range of motion, the exercise, etc. Uh, and including the rate of perceived exertion or what other subjective metric or even objective if you're using a velocity tracker or something. You're able to keep those things the same from work out to work out and increase the weight. That is a demonstrable increase in performance. You're able to progressively load the person. So increase the training stimulus without necessarily altering the training stress. The training stress is about the same. So this is going to require us to go over some definitions. So let's talk about those now. First definition is going to be training stimulus. These are the nuts and bolts of a program like the exercises, the reps schemes, the rep ranges, the intensity, rest periods, the tempo of the movement or velocity, range of motion, etc. This can also be conceptualized as the external load. The training stress is the resultant load placed upon the individual based on their current level of fitness and performance potential and everything that goes into that. Like their mood, their training expectations, nutrition status, fatigue, etc. This can also be classified as the internal load and can be measured by rate of perceived exertion, changes in heart rate, etc. Fitness adaptations are the positive, physiological, and psychological effects of exercise, like strength, hypertrophy, cardiovascular fitness, improved cognitive performance, etc. Fatigue can be conceptualized as the negative, physiological, and psychological effects of exercise. Things like soreness, muscle damage, reduced force production, tiredness, etc. Performance potential is the ratio or balance of fitness adaptations relative to fatigue at any given point in a specific environment for completing a particular task. Thus, training stimulus produces a given training stress that is unique to the individual, which subsequently results in both fitness adaptations and fatigue. If, over a given period of time, fatigue is greater than fitness adaptations, performance declines even if fitness adaptations are accruing. They're just being hidden or cloaked by fatigue. If fitness adaptations are greater than the resulting fatigue, performance potential can be realized if the environment is correct. Overall, the goal of training is to develop and realize fitness adaptations over time. So how does this fit in with progressive overload? The principle of progressive overload suggests that the human body must be continually challenged by greater and greater training stimuli over time in order to drive fitness adaptations. If taking at face value, I would pretty much agree with that. Though I think in practice, this gets misunderstood and misapplied, because really the adaptation rate determines the rate at which the training stimuli must increase. Rather than the increase in training stimuli determining the adaptation rate. In other words, applying the right dose of training stimulus based on individual's goals, their current fitness and performance levels, the environment and so on, is of primary importance. If the increase in training stimulus occurs too quickly, we're likely to also get too much fatigue on board, which reduces performance potential, can increase injury risk and may not actually lead to greater fitness adaptations anyway. Similarly, if we increase the training stimulus too slowly, the rate of fitness adaptation accrual will be decreased. In both cases, if the training stimulus is not matched to the individual's current fitness and performance potential, they're unlikely to get the best results. That can also work in reverse, that in order to get the best results, the training stimulus must be matched to the individual's current fitness and performance potential. In other words, the person's adaptation rate, which is reflected at any given point by their performance potential, should determine the training stimulus for the day. Because we have tools that allow us to determine an individual's performance potential on a given day, things like RPE, Reps and Reserve, Barvelocity, we're able to tailor the training stimulus on every training session for every movement in order to get the right dose. If fitness adaptations have accrued relative to fatigue, then an individual will be able to add something like weight, reps, reduced rest periods, something like that, while keeping the rest of the program the same. In other words, training stimulus has gone up while training stress has stayed about the same. So RPE has stayed the same, heart rate change has stayed the same, barvelocity has stayed the same. Again, the performance potential should determine the appropriate training stimulus on a given day. So what does this look like in practice? On the left, you have me squatting 600 pounds on the right, you have me squatting 6006, there are one week apart. The barvelocity is the same. I'm still doing the same reps, came it's a single rep. The RPE was about the same. I rated them both at about RPE 8 7 1.5 something like that. And so effectively, this is a demonstrable increase in performance potential that has then determined the training stimulus, the load on the bar. Because everything else about the program is static. If I had had an even greater increase in performance potential, I'd add even more weight to the bar. If I would have a decrease in performance potential, I'd have to take weight off the bar. And if my performance potential didn't increase at all, I would have to repeat the weight. And that's fine. Again, it is the performance potential, which is a proxy for the adaptation rate that determines the appropriate training stimulus. Not the training stimulus and increase in training stimulus determining the adaptation rate. Alright, last example is going to be my deadlift here. So we have 705 on the left, 7 17 on the right, doing them both for a single. They should be about RPE 8 and we'll look at the barvelocity. They're about the same. If not, maybe a little faster on the 7 17. Again, this represents a demonstrable increase in performance potential, which is then determined the training stimulus. So why do it this way versus just adding weight to the bar indiscriminately or changing weight on the bar or changing rep schemes indiscriminately? And by indiscriminately, I mean irrespective of what the RPE is, what the RIR is, what the velocity of the barvelocity is. Well, the point is that if you are generating too much fatigue out of proportion to the fitness adaptations on board, then the reality is you're trying to maximize performance on a given training session. And for most training sessions, particularly ones that are far away from a competition, a test, a need. You're really trying to just generate as many fitness adaptations as possible over time without generating too much fatigue. If you're generating all this fatigue, just so you can have the max performance on a single session, but that session wasn't really that important, that's kind of a waste. And so I think that most of your sessions should be sub-maximal, should be not too fatiguing, and you can only go to the well so many times before it goes dry. You'll see an example of me going to the well and overshooting and trying to force weight on the bar. And I think that's appropriate when you're getting ready for a test or a meat, and you can only do it for a short period of time because again, the fatigue cost is very, very high. The meat coming up though, I'm willing to kind of do that in some settings, not obviously all of my lifts that would not work, even though I'm getting really close to the meat, but here and there, I'm okay with making that compromise. But if I was 16 weeks out, 20 weeks out or had no meat on the schedule, I wouldn't do that at all because again, all I'm doing is trying to maximize the performance of a single session with, you know, disregard to other upcoming sessions or past sessions. Again, the fatigue that I'm going to generate is just out of proportion to the potential fitness adaptations. Again, the take home from this is that your adaptation rate, and we can use a proxy performance potential to determine that, is what's going to determine the change in training stimulus, not the increase or change in training stimulus determining the adaptation rate. So hopefully that makes more sense from what progressive loading is, and I think where people get off track is when they hear the term overload, they're like, oh, I have to do more. It has to overload the body. Really, it all has to do is stress the body enough to drive the fitness adaptations that you want. And principally, it can't drive too much fatigue because if it does, then you're not going to realize those fitness adaptations anyway. So maybe we should just call it progressive loading and get over this whole progressive overload thing. I don't know. Let me know what you guys think in the comments. I'll talk about it more. We do have a podcast on this and I've linked that in the description below. Maybe we'll write a long form article on this if you guys want. Let me know here thoughts. Finally, let's get into some training from last week, again, five weeks out, and I'll be interested to hear what you guys think about next week's vlog with the training from four weeks out. It gets a little dice in there. All right, so this is day one starting off again. It's a score up or so this is 275 kilos or 606. I'm going to do this for a single. I had done 600 of the week before pretty happy with how that move that might be last warm up. This is just a back offset. This is to 20 kilos, so 484. I did a couple sets of five with this. That's what makes me look half way presentable. When I'm lifting weights, got a road video mic pro mic on there and then this is a newer tripod. And it like extends and whatever. All right. So now let's take a look at this past week's training, again, a seven weeks out last week, six weeks out this week. So last week was actually a D load week. It was my first D load week in about 20 weeks. So the previous mesocycle is actually very productive. And so before we kind of dive into the lifts, I actually did just a brief word on D load weeks. I don't think that we should be taking D load weeks on a regularly scheduled basis. Unless there's like a firm concrete, not arbitrary date that you need to peak for a meet a test competition, something like that, and need to transition your training before that to prepare adequately for that test meeting. If it's a pilot meeting, you're doing more singles, you're specializing the training to the movements that you're going to be tested on, stuff like that. If you don't have to do that, or if your test is kind of flexible, meaning that you could go test your lifts in the gym whenever you want to, I don't think that you need to plan D loads. If your training is working for you right now, you're highly motivated for what you're doing, like carry on until proven otherwise. On the other hand, there are two basic categories that like would prompt me to give somebody a D load one is psychological and one is physiological. So psychological, if somebody is bored, they are not motivated, or they are otherwise like having compromised adherence or really stagnant with respect to their attitudes towards training. Hey, let's change training up and two transition into that next block. Let's do a D load week. On the physiology side, I'm thinking more like persistent soreness fatigue, maybe an injury, or pain that thing that's kind of crept up and we need to transition anyways into something that more meets the person where they're at. But the idea is that if your programming regularly requires D loads like every fourth week, I don't know that the thing is programmed very well. A lot of our templates do have regularly programmed D load weeks. But the idea is that we're trying to build a template for the general population and on average, most mesocycles that are well programmed are going to last somewhere between four to eight weeks depending on the goal and the population that you're applying the training to. But like I said, my previous mesocycle lasted 20 weeks. And again, the only reason we kept running it with just small tweaks here and there to maybe movements and maybe total training stress, yeah, it just kept working. So if your training is working and you're motivated and you're not having this persistent fatigue or soreness or anything else that's compromising your training, like carry on. That would be my recommendation. Okay, so with that out of the way, what are the goals of A D load week? What you'd like to do is to prepare the individual or that lifter for the next training block, whether there's new movements, new rep schemes, stuff like that. That's a good place to kind of introduce those things. So that way they can hit the ground running. Another thing that is pretty consistent across all different types or styles of D load weeks is to reduce the amount of fatigue that the individual is carrying so they can be more fresh leading into the next training block. And so what you're going to see is a reduction in training stress, training stress being the training intensity. So how heavy it is, the training volume, you're going to see market reductions and usually both of those things. And though the reduction in sort of training stress typically leads to a reduction in training load, which leads to a decrease in fatigue. Now the thing is if you just did nothing, no training at all. The problem with it isn't that you wouldn't dissipate fatigue. You certainly would. The problem is that you're also decaying a lot of the fitness adaptations or reducing a lot of the fitness adaptations that you previously built over your previous training block or blocks. And so you'd like to preserve those to the best of your ability. So we're talking about things like strength. We're talking about things like power, things like lean body mass, cardiovascular risk perifitness of those power and strength probably are the ones most likely to decay without any sort of training because of the skill component there. Meaning that you're unlikely to after-feed significantly, even if you don't train for a week, provided you're eating enough protein and not, you know, confined to bed rest or ill, same thing with cardiovascular fitness. But you can definitely get weaker, noticeably weaker in a week if you're not doing any sort of training, just because of the high skill nature of resistance training, particularly maximal force production at low velocities or like power lifting. Same thing, a little bit with a Olympic weightlifting or power sort of exercises like that that do have a high skill component. So in this context, in a D-load week, you'd like to give people a little bit of strength work to maintain their strength, right? Make sure they get a pretty decent pump, get some blood flow, and overall lower training stress so that they can be less fatigue for the next training block. And that's what we're going to see this week in my D-load week. All right, so this is a day one, pretty much every training day. There's a bench, there's a squat and then some sort of pull or row. So this one's supposed to work up to a set of 10 at 8, believe this is 320. === FILE: Two Minute Tuesday： Resistance Training for Injury Risk Reduction in Endurance Athletes [mA8U-otQlp8].txt ===

Hey everyone, welcome back to the Barbell Medicine YouTube channel where we bring modern medicine to strengthen conditioning, a strength of conditioning to modern medicine, I'm your host, Dr. Jordan Fyginbob, and this is a two minute Tuesday. We haven't done one of these in a while. We have a very special article series and we just released the first part of it. This is by Dr. Derek Miles and he's got input from Dr. Austin Baraki, Dr. Michael Ray, and a handful of other professionals. This stuff is really good. We're going to talk about resistance training for endurance athletes. Part one is all about injury risk reduction using resistance training. This is a very cool topic. Hopefully I can incentivize you to read the long form article. I've put the link in the description below and I can give you some take home pearls that will be useful to you. Let's take a few minutes and talk about reducing injury risk using resistance training in endurance athletes. To begin the prevalence of injuries in endurance athletes is pretty high between 20 and about 80%. When we look at why injury rates are so high in this group, we should turn to the literature again. A recent systematic review demonstrated little correlation between biomechanical risk factors and injury. Now, the most common subgroup of endurance athletes to be injured are novices with about 17.8 injuries per thousand participation hours compared to more seasoned runners, which have about 7.7 injuries per thousand participation hours. The biggest risk factor for why novices tend to have more injuries than seasoned runners is due to a training history that is they don't really have this base of training that they've built up over time that they get to add stress to. The biggest predictor actually of injury risk in this population is the history of having an injury, which is unfortunate because that's a non-modifiable risk factor if you've had an injury before. Can't really go back and eliminate that. That being said, another big predictor of injury risk in this population would be lack of appropriate prior training and a rapid increase in workload. We see the same thing in resistance training. Now that we've talked about the prevalence and the risk factors for developing an injury, let's talk about some specific ones and see if there's anything we can do in order to prevent these. So first, let's talk about Patelofemeral Paincinder. Also known as runners, knee. It's one of the most common kinds of knee pain. Usually characterized by pain around the knee cap or under the knee cap, not lateralized to one side or another. Another common injury will be tendonopathy is this refers to a continuum of tendon changes that are all related to collagen. Including disruption, inflammation, and cellular responses. Next type of injury would be hamstring strains and this is usually due to high velocity running or occurs in the context of sprinting things like that. The next injury after that, it's very common in this endurance population would be bone stress injuries like shin splints or medial tibial stress syndrome and stress fractures. These tend to happen on a continuum in response to the bones inability to handle repetitive mechanical loading, which ultimately leads to structural fatigue. And overall, the data suggests that 50 to 75% of running related injuries are related to overuse. I.e. an increase in training stress that occurs to rapidly and the majority of these occur in the lower extremity around the knee, which again, if you think about what we just talked about, Patelofemeral Paincinder, tendonopathy, hamstring strains, bone stress injuries, particularly of the lower extremity. These are all again around the knee. As far as treatments at present, we have evidence on stretching, eccentric exercise, and heavy slow resistance training, which is effectively weightlifting. And we can talk about each one of those with respect to reducing injury risk in runners specifically. So let's talk about stretching first. And I know what you're thinking, Barbo Medicine, talking about stretching, it's not what you think. Right now, the most current, a cochlear review on interventions for preventing running related injuries. This is from 2011. Success that stretching, in fact, does not reduce the risk of injuries. Another systematic review of this topic from Laurason in 2014 suggested that stretching is not an effective way of reducing injury risk in runners. And also, that if they were to resistance training, instead, that reduced all injuries by a third and overuse injuries by a half. So potentially big improvement in injury risk reduction with resistance training. That being said, resistance training is fairly uncommon amongst endurance athletes. We look at the data from the National High School Stress Fracture Registry, suggest that 58% of these high school athletes didn't engage in any form of resistance training at all. And that's in the athletic population. In the general population, we see that 2018 physical activity guidelines for adults actually recommend resistance training for all adult Americans, at least twice per week. However, based on 2017 data from the National Health Interview Survey, only 23 and a half percent of all Americans are actually meeting this minimum guidelines. Those who do, however, have a 23% reduction in all cause mortality. So obviously, there's a huge benefit for engaging in resistance training in both athletic and the general population. However, it's likely being underutilized and even underdosed in both populations. Now that we've discussed some of these common injuries in runners, let's see how resistance training can actually reduce injury risk in this population. So for a Patelofemeral Pain Syndrome, remember that was the pain that is around the knee and under the kneecap. The most recent Cochrane Review for treatment of Patelofemeral Pain Syndrome showed that exercise therapy had consistent results for improving functional ability and reducing pain. For hamstring sprains, again, remember this occurs in the context, usually of high velocity running or sprinting. It's typically thought to be due to lack of hamstring e-centric strength. And so one way to develop that is by using the Nordic hamstring curl. Now, you guys may have noticed that I actually have made a Nordic hamstring video how to. That's because I'll rehab professionals and our coaches wanted a resource that they could use for their clients instead of referring people all over the internet. Put a link to that video in the description below so you guys can check that out. We actually have a lot of data on the Nordic hamstring curl as far as prevention of injury and we can calculate what's called a number needed to treat. Now, a number needed to treat effectively stands for how many people do you need to give the intervention to prevent the outcome that you're studying. And so the number needed to treat for the Nordic hamstring curl is three, meaning that you need to treat three people to do the Nordic hamstring protocol to prevent one hamstring strain. And this is really good for a lifestyle intervention number needed to treat standpoint. So if you consider the Mediterranean diet at preventing cardiovascular disease, the number needed to treat for that intervention is 61. And we're comparing that to three for the Nordic hamstring curl. So again, a lot of data, a lot of good potential benefits from improving the eccentric strength of the hamstrings with respect to decreasing hamstring sprain incidence. So the next injury we'll talk about would be bone stress injuries. This would be the stress fractures and the shin splints and similar injuries that we talked about earlier. So the data suggests that endurance athletes tend to have lower bone mineral densities as measured by dexascant compared to their peers who play other sports. And resistance training has been shown to increase bone mineral density. And this is one of the most potent interventions we can give people to actually build up their bone mineral density while they're younger, so that fractures and other issues stemming from low bone mineral density and old age don't crop up. The last thing we'll talk about from an injury perspective would be low back pain. Surle at al analyzed interventions for treatment of low back pain and found support for recommending strengthening exercises for the treatment of low back pain. However, this doesn't mean that having a stronger low back or bigger back muscles actually prevents low back pain. Rather, the actual engagement in resistance training is a good treatment for people who have low back pain to not only get them back to function but also decrease their low back pain. So now that we've talked about the prevalence of injury rates in endurance training, a few common ones and how resistance training can help, what about the risk of resistance training overall? Isn't it dangerous just to lift weights? So one of the best studies on this is from 2016, a systematic review by Q at al found that for most weight training sports, the average injury rate was about one to two injuries per athlete per year or two to four injuries per thousand participation hours. And this included things like bodybuilding, power lifting, weight lifting, strongman, highling games and even crossfit, although it is true that strongman and highland games tend to have higher injury rates. Somewhere in that five to six injuries per thousand participation hours. And when you compare that to the injury rates from recreational walking and cycling to work, which can reach as high as 1.5 injuries per thousand participation hours, maybe we should be more concerned about the risk of injury from not resistance training, than the actual risk of injury from resistance training. I think that resistance training offers a very potent intervention that is underutilized and again, underdosed likely in both the general and athletic populations. So hopefully I've convinced you to go read the long form article over on the boardalmedicine.com website. I've put the link in the description below. And if you like the video, make sure you hit subscribe for all the latest content. Leave us a comment below, share it with your friends. We'll see you guys next time. Later.

=== FILE: When Should You Seek Treatment For Pain？ [gbT2RaI4B_w].txt ===

Is it ever, ever? This was an interesting word. Worthwhile, to seek treatment for chronic non-specific pain. Yes. Well, I think it's worth while to seek treatment for pain period. I assume this question probably means use of pain medications, but I'm not going to say that that means treatment. So, treatment would be seen a clinician being evaluated for potential causes of pain involving the patient, exploring this bio-psychocossocial model together, coming up with a shared management plan, and moving forward from there. So, I would say if a person has pain and they're concerned about it, see your medical professional. If it's from training, my caveat would be hopefully they're very familiar with pain science. And unfortunately, I don't feel confident that that is the case. I'm not going to try to throw shade at the medical establishment. It's just, look, I'm in the medical establishment, and I know that that's the case right now. So, I think, like our pain rehab specialist team, those guys are the best in the business, and that would be my general recommendation for somebody who's got pain from training. And they're like, I need some professional help. But I think if somebody has pain that concerns them, they're worried about our specific thing. They're like, oh, I have this low back pain and I'm worried it could be cancer. It sounds crazy, but that's not an unusual sort of report. Like, oh, yeah, my dad had the same sort of pain and he had cancer, and that's why I'm afraid. Yeah, seeking treatment, because you're going to be evaluated, and then treated based on fine names, and then, again, you as the complex patient, ideally, that would be a net benefit. I don't know that you need pain medications necessarily, which I assume is, again, what this question actually meant. I don't know what it implied. When I read the question, I said, I hope I didn't convey the message during my lecture, that it's not worth seeking help for pain related issues, because that's certainly not the case. Yeah, in fact, the opposite. Yeah, it's very common for people to need help. I think that we definitely provided you with information, education, hopefully empower you to self-manage many of your, like, common routine day to day aches and pains, type situations, but to the extent that you're dealing with something, a pain related issue, that maybe you don't fully know what to do, or you've tried what you've learned, and you can't make progress, then seeking out some consultation, evaluations, some assistance from somebody you trust, would be a fantastic idea. Now, we cannot guarantee that that person will do, will offer you, will recommend to you, unless it's somebody from our own rehab team. I've definitely seen patients who end up seeing a pain specialist or something, and bad things end up getting ruled out, and they get a prescription for an opioid. That probably wouldn't be the case that I would go with this myself. Nor would it be the way that our rehab team would go. So we have a resource that we can offer that we trust and recommend without reservation. But if you are struggling with an issue like this, then seeking help is definitely the way to go. Would recommend. Would recommend. Yes. All right. Thank you.
